stealing, on the 19th of August , 4 live tame ducks, price 10s. , the property of
Mary Harmer
.
MARY HARMER. The prisoner is my grandson. On the 19th of August I lost these ducks, and accused him of taking them; he denied it, but owned afterwards that he had; he is a poor distressed creature.

HENRY DELLER
. I am a Police-constable. I took the prisoner on the 19th of August; he owned that he took them.

JAMES VAUGHAN
. The prisoner sold me four ducks and a drake for 4s., on the 19th of August.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1704.
ELIZA MUNRO
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of February , 1 shawl, value 1l. 10s.; 1 gown, value 10s.; 2 shifts, value 5s.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 1 pair of gloves, value 1s.; 1 ring, value 8s.; 1 pair of drawers, value 3s., and 1 book, value 8s. , the goods of
Henry Johnson
.

MARY JOHNSON
. I am the wife of
Henry Johnson
- he lives in John-street, Oxford-street
. On the 8th of February I lost these articles; they were in a back room in which I was sitting - the book was on a table, the gloves behind some glasses, the shawl over a clothes-horse, and the other articles were in my bed-room; the prisoner succeded my sister in a situation, and my sister brought her to see me - she came on the 6th of February, and asked if I could tell her of a situation; I said No, but I could let her sleep there for two nights; on the 8th I was sitting at work, and she said she would go and get her bundle, and go to her place - instead of taking them, she was taking these from me; I have only found the shawl.

Prisoner. Q. Did not I bring a bundle of clothes to your room? A. No, only a bundle of grass, which deceived me; I did not say my sister took a silver ring away - you said you were going to live as servant at No. 8, Harley-street.

WILLIAM CUNNINGHAM
. I took the prisoner on the 6th of August - the prosecutor's sister was present; she said it was poverty that determined her to take them, but she meant to return them, and make some recompence - she had this shawl on.

Prisoner's Defence. I had pawned my own shawl onthe 7th of February, and given her 3s. - she lent me this till I could get my own, but as I could not get it her, I sent it; she was not Mrs. Johnson then.
MARY JOHNSON. I have been married seventeen months.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1705.
THOMAS EVANS
and
ELIZA EVANS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of August , 4lbs. weight of bacon, value 2s.; 9 eggs, value 6d., and 1lb. of butter, value 10d. , the goods of
James Savage
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

JAMES SAVAGE
. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Camden-row, Bethnal-green-road
;
Thomas Evans
was my shopman - he resided in my house, and had to open the shop about seven o'clock in the morning; I placed the greatest confidence in him - he had been sixteen months in my service; some suspicion arose in my mind- on the 3rd of August I went down into the cellar, and concealed myself under the window, where I could see and hear what passed in the shop; he opened the shop about seven o'clock, and soon after Eliza Evans, his sister,(the other prisoner) came in - there was a man then in the shop; she waited till he was gone, and when
Thomas Evans
had served the customer he went to the butter-scale, took a piece of butter, put it on another piece, and put it into this basket; he said, "You use a precious sight of butter, I don't know what you do with it" - he had not weighed it, and no money passed between them; he then went to the counter on the other side, and said to her, "Has mother sent those things?" she said, "No, she was out all day yesterday;" he said, "I will blow her up well. she ought not to mind what she does for me, see what I do for her"- he was then in the act of cutting a cushion of bacon; he cut off, I think, not less than 4lbs., but did not weigh it, nor appear to take any money, or change any - he put that into a piece of paper, and then into the basket; she then said to him, "Mother says she wants," but the remainder of the sentence I could not catch - he said, "I shall do no such thing, take what you have got, and be contented"- he was then going to a basket of eggs, and took out as many as he could hold in two hands; he put them into the basket; Eliza Evans shut down the lid, and went away - I came up the cellar stairs in about a minute, and made a signal, which had been agreed on, to my friend Shields, which was to throw out my arm; I then turned to
Thomas Evans
, and said, "Well, Thomas, how long has this game being going on?" he said, "What game, Sir?" I said, "What has just taken place;" he affected not to understand me - I said, "Very well, I will see about it;" I went to the door, and saw the Policeman - I gave him in charge; he then asked for forgiveness, and said it was the first time - I had not made him any promise or threat; the child was brought forward afterwards.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. In what situation is the door? A. In the centre - the right-hand is the butter side, and the other the bacon side; the bacon window was covered over - I could see what I have stated; there was a - lb. weight in the scale previous to his placing the butter into it, but he did not weigh it - I had no character with him; his clothes went home to be washed - I believe this girl sometimes brought his things; his mother dealt with me, but very seldom had credit; I never recollect this little girl fetching things on credit - I think he was taken in about ten minutes afterwards; he could not intend to place them down to his mother, as he did not weigh them - this little girl is from eleven to twelve years of age; she was taken at Bethnal-green, about two hundred yards from my shop.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. You say there was a - lb. weight in the scale? A. yes, but the quantity of butter he gave her was from 1 lb. to 1 1/2lb. - he did not weigh the bacon, nor appear to count the eggs.

ANDREW WILLIAM SHIELDS
. By desire of the prosecutor I waited at some distance from his shop - there was a lad placed opposite, who was to convey the intelligence to me; I had been watching two mornings before in the same place, and had seen this little girl each of those mornings, about seven o'clock - on the third morning I received intimation from my boy; I waited till she came to the corner, at the Salmon and Ball - I stopped her, and asked what she had in her basket; I do not recollect precisely what she said, but she wished to push me off, and would not allow me to see - I wished to take hold of the basket; she rather resisted - I took her into the Salmon and Ball, and examined the contents, which were these articles; I asked where she got them - she began to cry; I asked what she had in her other hand, and found this half-crown - she cried, and said she wanted to go to her mother.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see her enter the shop? A. Yes, but not come out; she went in about five minutes after seven o'clock, and we took her eight or ten minutes after.
- SHIELDS. I saw this little girl come out of the shop, and gave the signal to my father.

GEORGE ROBINSON
. I am a constable, and took her in charge.
Thomas Evans' Defence. It was my intention to book these things - I weighed them; Mr. Savage would not give me time to book them before he came out of the cellar.

THOMAS EVANS
-
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

ELIZA EVANS
-
NOT GUILTY .

1706.
HENRY DAVIES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 cruet-stand, value 10., and 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 5s. , the goods of
Joseph Poulton
.

HENRY AKER
. I am agent to Mr. Joseph Poulton. who is a tea-dealer , in the City. On the 1st of September. I was in the shop, at Hackney
, and passing the parlour-door I saw the prisoner - I went into the parlour. and he had this cruet-stand in his hand, which he had taken from the cupboard - I charged him with having stolen it; he said a lady sent him for it; he said it was his first offence, and wished me to let him go - I sent for an officer, and he found these sugar-tongs in his pocket, which are also the property of the prosecutor.

JOHN BEDFORD
. I am a Police-officer. I was sent for,and found these tongs; the stand, and these two dozen of pencils were on the table.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 14 -
Transported for Seven Years .

1707.
WILLIAM DOWNES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 cask, value 18d. , the goods of
Henry Bakewell
.
HENRY BAKEWELL. I am a hatter . I lost a cask, but cannot swear this is mine - I told the Magistrate so, and the prisoner was bailed.
NOT GUILTY .

1708.
MARY ANN KEWITT
,
JOHN GUBBY
, and
JOSEPH WASHINGTON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 1 shawl, value 2l. 5s.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s., and 3 handkerchiefs, value 15s. , the goods of
John Darling
.

JOHN DARLING. I am a mariner , and live in New Gravel-lane; I had been from sea eighteen months, and was lodging in the Commercial-road
, at Mrs. Kewitt's - Gubby stated that he was her husband; I lodged eleven days there - Washington was a waterman ; they charged me for a fortnight, but I was only there eleven days - I paid them 2l. 5s.; I had a bag there, containing a shawl. a waistcoat, three handkerchiefs, and other things - I left the bag there about five o'clock on the 31st of July and returned at half-past ten o'clock at night; I found it had been opened, and the property stated was missing - it was not tied as I had left it; the prisoners were all there - Washington passed as Kewitt's brother; I asked Kewitt if she knew any thing about the property - she said No, and gave me a good deal of abuse, and called me every thing that was bad; she began to find fault with my country first, and I could not stand that.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was this a lodging-house for mariners? A. I do not know whether it was for mariners or landsmen; there was only one other man there.

WILLIAM MITCHELL
. I am a Police-officer. The prosecutor came to me and said he had been robbed - I went to the house, and saw Kewitt and Gubby; he said they had robbed him - Kewitt said the ship's carpenter, who lodged in the house, had taken the things away; I took her into custody, and afterwards found two handkerchiefs at different pawnbrokers.

JAMES TYLER
. I am a Police-officer. I took Washington, and found a duplicate of part of the property on him.

EDWARD SHAW
. I am a Policeman. I went with Mitchell; the prosecutor said he had been robbed in the house - Kewitt said another man had robbed him - the next morning I had a ticket given me of a shawl pawned by White.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you hear the ship-carpenter's name? A. No.
WILLIAM CLAYTON. White was given into my charge, Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did not the pawnbroker identify White as the person who pawned the goods? A. I believe so.

FREDERICK LANCE
. I am a pawnbroker. This handkerchief was pawned by Washington in the name of Joseph Washington.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. What day was this? A. On the 4th of August; I had never seen him before- I swear he is the man; he gave his address, No. 2, Stepney-causeway - the handkerchief is hemmed, and I think it has been washed.

MATTHEW POULTER
. I have a duplicate, stating that a shawl, a waistcoat, and a handkerchief were pawned on the 21st of July, and redeemed on the 30th, by a female, for Kewitt.

GEORGE WHIPPER
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a silk handkerchief, pawned by Powell, in the name of Mary Powell.

ELIZABETH POWELL
. I pawned a handkerchief with this witness for Washington - it was something similar to this; I did not have it in my hand a minute.
Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Did you ever pawn before at that shop? A. Yes.

ANN WHITE
. I have been in the habit of pawning for Kewitt - I do not recollect pawning this red handkerchief; I am her sister - I remember the prosecutor living there; I do not remember his bag - I was not present when any person took any thing out of it; I have heard him say he had some handkerchiefs - my sister had them in her possession, I believe, by his wish; I pawned some goods for my sister, but they were folded up, and I do not know what they were - I gave them to the pawnbroker; I believe they generally open articles, but I was in a hurry, and did not take notice.
THOMAS DARLING. These are my handkerchiefs.

Cross-examined by CLARKSON. Q. What is the name of the carpenter? A. Alexander; he lodged with me all the time, but went away that night, and went on board the smack to Scotland - my handkerchiefs were not hemmed, nor washed.
Washington's Defence. These are my handkerchiefs - I believe the young woman is here, who knows I bought them of a butcher.

WASHINGTON -
GUILTY . Aged 33.
Transported for Seven Years .

KEWITT -
NOT GUILTY .

GUBBY -
NOT GUILTY .

1709.
JAMES QUICK
and
JOHN WILLIAMS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , 1 handkerchief. value 2s., the goods of
John George Michele
, from his person .

JOHN GEORGE MICHELE
. I am a surgeon , and live at No. 31, Upper Charlotte-street, Fitzroy-square. At eleven o'clock in the forenoon, on the 20th of July, I was in St. James'-park
, and lost my handkerchief at the review of the troops - I did not feel any thing, but a person told me my pocket had been picked; I turned round, and saw the officer with my handkerchief; the officer had one of the prisoners, and another person the other.

ANGELIOUS BETRAUN
. I was at the review - I saw the prosecutor; the two prisoners were together behind him- Williams turned from him with a yellow handkerchief in his hand; I seized him - he threw himself on the ground, and endeavoured to put it between the feet of the people; Quick covered him while he took it - I took him and the handkerchief; another man took Quick.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Quick's Defence. All of a sudden this man came and laid hold of me, and charged me with stealing this handkerchief - my mistress, who was with me, stepped up and said I had nothing to do with it; she came to the office, but I was committed.
Williams' Defence. I was going on an errand for my mother, and saw the handkerchief on the ground - I took it up; I never saw this boy before.

QUICK -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

WILLIAMS -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Confined Three Months .

1710.
THOMAS LILEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 1 looking-glass, value 5s.; 1 set of fire-irons, value 3s., and 1 piece of bed-furniture, value 1s. , the goods of
Thomas Fawcett
.

REBECCA FAWCETT
. I am the wife of Thomas Fawcett; we lived in Frederick's-place, Hampstead-road, but we lost these articles from No. 70, Charlotte-street
, on the 12th of July - the prisoner watched me out.

JANE WILLIAMS
. The prisoner came to my house on the 12th of July, with a load of goods, and inquired for a lodger named Smith - I said they were both out, and I could not give him leave to bring those goods into another person's apartments, but most likely he could get a room in the neighbourhood; he said it was not many persons who would like to take him in at that time of night - it was then between eight and nine o'clock; he said he had a van of goods in May's-buildings, and he had authorized Mr. Smith to take a room to put the goods in.

REBECCA FAWCETT re-examined. The prisoner had been in my husband's employ - he took him in out of charity; I had given him my key to take these articles to my apartment - he brought me the key, and said he had put every thing in correct; on the Sunday morning before the 12th of July, he told me a gentleman had been on business, and I had better go and state the business to him - I went, and while I was gone, he took every thing away from the room; he went in with false keys, which were taken from him by the officer - it was household furniture and my own wearing-apparel; I was out at the time - I came home, and slept there, but did not miss the things till the next morning; they had been in a back garret - I did not part with the property; the witness does not live in the same house - I never authorized the prisoner to take any of the goods; I lost more goods than these.

JANE WILLIAMS re-examined. I would not let him put them into my place, but I went out, and he brought them in in my absence - when I came home, part of the goods were in the room, and part at the door; on the 13th the prisoner offered some of these things for sale, and I bought a bed, a looking-glass, and fire-irons - he said they were his, and he got his living by buying and selling goods.

GEORGE FORD
. I am a Police-constable. On the 12th of July I heard the prosecutrix had been robbed of some furniture - I went to the lodgings, and found these articles; I took up Smith, who lodged at Williams' - on the 13th the prisoner made a sale of some of them, and on the 14th he removed some to Luke-street, Tabernacle-walk; I found on him these keys - they open the prosecutrix's door; I took from him 4l. 11s. 5d.
Prisoner. The prosecutrix knew I had two keys.
REBECCA FAWCETT. It is no such thing - I lost 27l. or 28l. worth of goods.

Prisoner's Defence. About Christmas last the prosecutor took me into his employ; he was arrested, and confined in the Marshalsea-prison, and the house in Hampstead-road was entrusted to my care - he gave orders for his property to be sold off, as it was his intention to take the benefit of the Act; his wife took a place in my name, and some goods were removed there for sale - part was deposited with Captain Orton, to be made away with; the prosecutor then made oath that he was not worth 10l., that he might get at liberty without taking the benefit of the Act, but being informed his intentions were not so good as his promises, I was determined to take possession of the property for which I now stand indicted; I had legal power to enter, as the house was taken in my name, and as I had a key, and had access to the property; I went to the prosecutor in prison - he desired me to get rid of the best part of the property, and not to let more than 10l. worth be in the shop; the goods appropriated to my use in the Hampstead-road were said to be mine, to reduce the property under 10l.; I therefore leave it to your consideration whether I had not a right to pay myself.

REBECCA FAWCETT
. There is no truth in this - my husband never employed him or authorized him to take away goods to reduce the property under 10l.; he has not taken the benefit of the Act, nor compounded with his creditors - it is all false - two boxes of this was my wearing-apparel.

Prisoner. Q. For what purpose was this lodging taken? A. For the purpose of living there; my husband was arrested for 40l., and I could not keep on the house - I never could go out but I lost something, and my husband said I had better remove; he is now in the Marshalsea - no portion of the goods were sold.
COURT. Q. Did you authorize him to sell it? A. No- I do not know how he came by the key; I never allowed him one - I had but one.
Prisoner. Q. Was not the room taken in my name? A. No, in my own - he wished me to take it in his name, but I would not; he came to us in the cold weather, and we took him in out of charity.

GUILTY . Aged 27. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1711.
ELIZABETH PIPER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 pillow, value 2s.; 1 coat, value 3s., and 1 frock, value 18d. , the goods of
William Martin
.

PRUDENCE MATILDA MARTIN
. I am the wife of
William Martin
, of Cottage-place, City-road
- I have known the prisoner about six years: I employed her six months ago at the straw business . On the 13th of August I missed these articles from my drawer - the prisoner then lived in the house, and I paid her for her work; she was taken, and the duplicate of the pillow was found upon her- I found nothing else.

JOHN GREEN
. I took the prisoner on the 16th of August - I found this duplicate upon her; she said she had left the cloak in Rose-lane, but I could not find it.

CHARLES WILLIAMS
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. I have a pillow pawned for 1s.; I cannot say by who - I gave this duplicate for it.
MRS. MARTIN. This is mine; I never allowed her to pawn it - she had a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.
OLD COURT. WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 22.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1712.
ELLEN CARROLL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 1 pair of boots, value 3s., 1 frock, value 1s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
George Peek
.

- PEEK. I am the wife of
George Peek
, and live in Tennis-court
- the prisoner has lodged with us for two years; her husband is a tailor. On the 21st of August I went out, between ten and twelve o'clock, leaving my things in my room - I returned about four, and missed them - I had left my girl at home to attend to a sick child, and she might have left the door open; I never allowed her to pawn any thing.

THEOPHILUS FENTON
. I am a pawnbroker, of Gray's Inn-lane. I have a pair of trousers and a frock-tail, pawned by the prisoner.

WILLIAM DEAN
. I have a pair of shoes, pawned by the prisoner in her own name - I live in Holborn.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. She lent me the things to pawn: I was to have got them out on the Saturday night.
MRS. PEEK. I swear I never knew it.

GUILTY . Aged 37. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1713.
JAMES FLOWERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 1 knot, value 6d.; 1 hat, value 6d., and 1 sovereign , the property of
Robert Fisher
.

ROBERT FISHER. I am a cork-cutter , and live in Aldermanbury - I have known the prisoner three or four years - he was occasionally in my employ. On the 18th of June I sent him from my house to fetch a bundle of cork from Ryder's-court, Leicester-fields
; I gave him a sovereign to pay for it, and lent him my knot and hat - he never returned, but came in July, and I gave him in charge- he said he had lost the sovereign, and worn the hat out in doing porter's work at different markets, and was ashamed to return - I applied at his lodging the night this happened; he was not at home.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Confined Three Months .

1714
MARY BAKER
was indicted for
stealing. on the 1st of August , 1 watch, value 6l. , the goods of
George Nuttress
.

GEORGE NUTTRESS. I am a stone-mason . On the 1st of August, about half-past three o'clock in the morning, I had been drinking with some friends, but was sober - I met the prisoner in Strutton-ground; she asked me home, but instead of taking me home she took me to another house in the Almonry
; I went into a bed-room up one pair of stairs - I was on the bed, but my clothes were not off; in about five minutes she made an excuse to go down stairs for water, and did not return; I had given her 1s. - I felt and missed my watch, which was safe in my pocket when I went into the room - I gave information at the watch-house; I went with Wilkins to another house, and found her; it was not the house I had been to with her - he found my watch under her in the bed; it has my name on it.

JOSEPH WILKINS
. I am a constable. I had seen the prosecutor with the prisoner about half-past three o'clock- he afterwards informed me he had been robbed; I went to her lodging, at No. 1. Duck-lane, and asked what she had done with the watch - there were two men in her bed, and I found the watch tucked into the bed; she was hiding herself behind the door.
Prisoner's Defence. I got behind the door to let them in - he came, and asked me for the duplicate; I said he had given it to me, and he fetched a Policeman.

GUILTY . Aged 17. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Baron Bolland.

1715.
MICHAEL McCARTHY
was indicted for the
wilful murder of
Eleanor McCarthy, alias Robinson, alias Rowberry
.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

CHRISTIAN ROWBERRY. My mother and the prisoner lived together as man and wife, at No. 13, Park-street, Poplar
; I cannot say whether they were married - he called her his wife, and treated her as such; I am her daughter by a former husband, and am twelve years old. On Saturday evening, the 11th of September , between five and six o'clock, the prisoner came home, and sat on a chair by the fire - he did not seem quite sober; my mother took a chair, and sat down facing him - he pulled 5s. out of his tobacco-box, and gave it to her; she said,"We are very rich - we owe 3s. for rent, and what am I to do with this small trifle?" she meant poor - he got up in a great rage seemingly, and said, "Give it to me, I know what to do with it;" my mother said, "Oh no I wont give it to you, it don't belong to you;" he then gave her a blow on the temple with his double fist, with great violence - she did not fall; she had got up when he did, before the blow was given; the place turned red directly - we were in the front parlour; she then went out of the room into the kitchen; she shut the door, leaving me in the parlour - there are two kitchens down stairs; he walked about the room, and seemed in a great passion - my mother offered him no violence at all; in the course of a little time he went down stairs; he heard my mother speaking, I believe - I did not go down; I heard my mother scream as soon as he went down stairs, and I screamed also; he came up stairs after staying down there about a quarter of an hour, and then went out, but my mother came up stairs first, went out, and then he went out - my mother had come up stairs first; she did not enter the room where he was, but opened the street door and went out; he was in the room with me; he took his son out with him - my mother came in in about an hour, about nine o'clock; I observed then that her temple was very black, and she complained very much of her breast - that was all she complained of; she began to get tea ready, and while she was getting it, the prisoner came in - he did not say a word to her that I heard, nor did she say any thing to him - she put a cup and sancer before him, and began to pour him out some tea; he said,"You need not pour any out for me, I don't want any;" my mother said, "Then there is more for them that do;" be kept nagging at her - she said she did not want any discourse with him, for he was a drunken man and a brutein heart; he got up and said, "If you don't go out, I will kick you out;" she said, "You need not do that, for I can go out," and she went - my father went out in two or three minutes; my mother came in in about half an hour, and asked me if he was gone out - I said Yes; he did not come in all night - I saw him between one and two o'clock on Sunday morning; that was the first time he came in - nothing passed for about five minutes; my mothere would have said nothing to him at all, but his little boy was looking very steadfastly at him; my mother said, "Come away, child, for he is no example for any child to look at, but to bring them to the gallows"- my father was very drunk then; he got up, and said,"What is that you say?" he made his way towards her, and she flew out of the room, down into Mrs. Ralph's kitchen, and he went after her - I heard her scream as soon as he went down, but do not know what passed, for I staid in the parlour; my feet and legs were as unwell as they are now (the witness was unable to walk) - I heard her scream two or three times; Mr. Ralph ran down stairs from his bed-room, and Mr. Lachmere, who lives in the house, ran down; after that my mother ran up to me, took me out of the room, and sat with me on the first floor stairs; I heard the prisoner while we were there, tell Mr. Ralph he should leave him to-morrow, and he was to give him a receipt - Ralph told him to go in and lay down, and he would give him a receipt to-morrow; he kept asking for the receipt, and at last went in, shut the room door, locked it, and laid down - we only had one room; he did not know we were on the stairs: my mother then took me down into the kitchen with her - this was about three o'clock in the afternoon; she got her dinner boiled on the kitchen fire, eat it, and then went up into her own room; a little boy picked the lock with a knife - she immediately brought some rags out of the room for her and me to lay on the kitchen floor - I laid on the rags, and she sat up in a chair which Mrs. Ralph lent her; she did not go into the room all night - my father and her were not together after he locked himself in the room; my mother laid down by me about eleven o'clock at night, and in a little time went to sleep, but I was awake all night - between twelve and one o'clock I heard my father out of his room, in the passage, saying, Oh! could he but find her he would kill her; when my mother awoke I told her what I had heard - she said something to me, and groans directly came into her throat, and she immediately died; she only said one word, which was asking me if my father said it loud - she had not been in liquor at all on Saturday, not before she died; she did not at any time lift her hand against the prisoner, to strike him - she died at three o'clock, exactly.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What is the name of your own father? A. Rowberry, in his own country language; he was a Sweed - I do not recollect him: my mother has lived with the prisoner since last summer twelve months - her name before that was
Ellen Robinson
- every body called us so, but her own name was Rowberry; the first house she lived at with the prisoner was in Catherine-street - she was known there by the name of
Eleanor Robinson
.

Q. Has she gone by the name of Robinson ever since the death of your father, till she lived with the prisoner? A. Yes - she was married to Rowberry at Islington church, but I cannot find any thing for it; when she lived with the prisoner she went by the name of Ellen McCarthy.
MR. BODKIN. Q. Do you mean that your mother's name was Ellen or Eleanor? A. Eleanor; when any body used to call her Ellen she would say her name was Eleanor.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. How came you to tell me her name was Ellen? A. I thought you asked me whether her name was Robinson - she used always to say her name was Eleanor; I have been ill since last March - the prisoner provided for us all; he worked at the West Indiadocks - he had only 12s. in his tobacco-box; there had been no liquor in the room that day - my mother was in her own room all day, cleaning up; it might be between seven and eight, or nine o'clock when she went out - I do not know where she went; she was gone about half an hour each time - it was on Sunday that she told his son not to look at him, &c.: he got up, and said, "What is that you say?" she made him no answer, but went down, and he after her - Ralph and Lachmere came down directly they heard her scream; we had only a few beef bones boiling for broth, for dinner on Sunday - she had nothing else, no beer of any kind, nor spirits; she had no supper - she walked out both times on Saturday, but when she came in she complained of her breast - she got up as usual on Sunday.

CATHERINE RALPH
. I keep the house in which the deceased lived; it is in the parish of All Saints, Poplar - the prisoner came home on the Saturday, between five and six o'clock; I was down in the kitchen, and heard words between them, but could not distinguish what passed; I looked up stairs and heard the deceased say,"Three shillings of this is owing for rent, and what am I to do with the remainder?" the prisoner said, "Give it me, I know what to do with it;" she said "No, it is owing elsewhere, it is not yours;" I looked up to the room, saw her coming out of their room door, and the prisoner struck her - I ran up stairs, and asked her to come down; he struck her on the left side of the head with his double fist; that was the first blow I saw - I was at the foot of the stairs, and could not see whether it was violent; I ran to her assistance, and saw it swell directly; she said to him, "Oh! you rogue; Oh! you villian, here is an eye you have given me;" she then gave me half a crown, went into her own room, and shut the door - I had some conversation with her about the half-crown, and am sure she knew perfectly well what she was doing - I went into my own apartment, and had not been long down stairs before words occurred between them again, and she came down to me - the prisoner came after her, and struck her two or three times; I screamed murder - I was so terrified - I cannot say where he struck her, but it appeared to me about her head, for I stood between them to part them, as well as I could - she and I both screamed Murder! they appeared to be violent blows - he appeared in great anger - I did not notice that he said any thing; Mrs. Lachmere, came down - she took hold of the prisoner, and asked if he knew what he was about - upon that he struck her over her shoulder - it struck his wife, and knocked her down; Mrs. Lachmere fell with her - she fell against the kitchen-table, and upset it; he then kicked his wife as she lay on the ground- he kicked her on the stomach, between the two breasts; that was done purposely, for I saw him look at her, lift his foot, and kick her with violence; Mr. Lachmere came down and persuaded him to go up to his own room - he went up with him - he said the quarrel had been about money - I heard him call Mr. Lachmere into his own room, and say, "Look her Lash., I have got half a sovereign, but that is owing elsewhere;" I heard no more that night - the deceased had not been into my room all Saturday, till this happened - I had seen her pass on the stairs - she had no appearance of being in liquor - she appeared in good health; I did not see or hear the prisoner again till between one and two o'clock on Sunday afternoon, when I was taking up my dinner; I heard words again, and the deceased ran down to my room, screaming violently; McCarthy followed her into the room - he struck her with his double fist; it appeared to me to be on the head or shoulder - I screamed for my husband, who came down directly - Mr. and Mrs. Lachmere came down after him - my husband took him by the collar, pulled him out of our room, and he challenged my husband to go to fight - he appeared in liquour; the poor woman afterwards got down some rags - I gave her two chairs to sit or in the empty kitchen, and there she died - I got up at half-past five o'clock; a medical gentleman was sent for, and examined her.
COURT. Q. Was it a kick or a stamp he gave her? A. A kick.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know the deceased before she lived with the prisoner? A. yes; she had lived with me in her first husband's time - he died at St. Kitt's; her name was Eleanor; I have heard her called Ellen - she answered to both names; she passed as the prisoner's wife - she always kept to her own room; she did not sit with me - she dined on Sunday about three o'clock, in the empty kitchen which I had lent her; I do not know whether she had been out that morning - she seemed to me to get the most blows about the head and shoulder, except the kick; the prisoner had offered to pay his rent and go directly - my husband said he should have the receipt tomorrow; Mr. Natorff was the first doctor that saw her, and he said she was not dead.

MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Did Mr. Natorff do any thing to her? A. Yes, he bled her - not above two drops came from her; he then had hot water put to her feet, and then he said she was dead - he was not present at the opening of her body.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did he not examine the whole of her person? A. he turned her round and examined her.

DOROTHY LACHMERE
. I lived at this house. I went down to the kitchen on Saturday - the prisoner knocked his wife and me down, and bruised my right shoulder and side; I saw him on Sunday strike at his wife again, but cannot say whether she received the blow.

RICHARD LACHMERE
. On the Saturday evening, between five and six o'clock, I was in Ralph's kitchen, and saw the prisoner kick his wife, but cannot say in what part of her body, as I was busy picking up my wife at the time.

JULIUS NATORFF
. I am a surgeon, and a native of France. I was called in at a quarter past six o'clock on Monday morning, and found the deceased's thorax and abdomen warm - I opened a vein, and got, I suppose, half an ounce of blood; I at first did not suppose life was extinct, but put her feet into warm water, and found she was dead - I examined her minutely outside, but was not present when the body was opened: I detected no appearance of bruises whatever - I could discern no cause of death.

Cross-examined. Q. Finding her still warm, life could not have been extinct long? A. No, but it is impossible to say how long; it might have been half an hour - I examined the chest between the breasts; there was no bruise of any kind to be seen.

Q. Supposing a violent kick to have been given between the breasts about noon, do not you think there must be some external mark? A. There would be a rupture of some small vessels, and an extravasation of blood, which would make its appearance at some time, but when, no medical man could tell - if the vessels are deep-seated the appearance would not be so quick; if she had been beat on the temple and swelling followed, there would have been some appearance of it - my examination did not lead me to form the least idea that she had died from personal violence: I have said, that to my judgment she died of apoplexy - I asked the beadle if I should open the body; he said he had a medical man of his own - it is usual when two medical men see a body, for both to be present at the opening.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. What are you? A. A surgeon; I keep an apothecary's shop at Limehouse, about ten minutes walk from where the woman died - I never saw her before.

MARMADUKE TATHAM
. I am a member of the Royal College of Surgeons, and am surgeon of Poplar parish for this year; the beadle requested I would go immediately and examine the deceased - he pointed the body out to me, laying on a bed-tick; several people were there - I observed a few slight contusions on the anterior part of the head, a little on one side, I think on the right, and about the fourth rib was another contusion; I cannot say on which said - I did not think it would be material, as I did not conceive any external appearance could be of any consequence; I examined the abdomen externally, and on the lower part of it was a discoloration on each side a little below the navel - perhaps a little more to the right than the left; I then opened the head, the dura mater was in a perfect uninflamed healthy state - the next two membraues were also uninflamed and healthy; the lobes of the cerebrum, both anterior and posterior, were perfectly healthy- it was the most healthy brain I ever saw; I found a slight degree of inflammation in the lungs commencing, but not sufficient, in my opinion, to cause death - I then examined the abdomen, and on laying bare the intestines, I found, a little below the smaller portion of the last intestine, which covers the ilium, in the highest degree of inflammatian, and a considerable quantity of serum and some portion of coagulum lymph in the cavity of the abdomen, which was the consequence of the inflammation - the uterus was also inflamed; these are the principal appearances I observed - I have every reason to conclude that the immediate cause of death was the inflammation of the intestines; the other causes had nothing whatever to do with the death, neither the signs about the head nor the inflammation of the lungs - I had frequently seen the woman before, having attended her child on the parish account; she was Mrs. McCarthy, and lived in Sophia-street, when I attended her - I never saw the prisoner till to-day.

Q. Could the appearances of inflammation, to which you ascribe her death, have been occasioned by a blow or kick in the stomach within twenty-four hours? A. There is no doubt of it; violence occasions inflammation, and there was every mark of inflammation and the result of violence - if it had been internal inflammation the appearance would have been very different; it was external inflammation - the Coroner and Jury viewed the body as I examined.

Cross-examined. Q. Your opinion is, that the inflammation of the ilium was the cause of her death? A. Certainly, that and no other - that intestine passes backwards and forwards in the lower part of the abdomen; it is principally below the navel; the jejunum begins where the ilium ends, but there is no fixed point of division, it is arbitrary - they are separated by an imaginary line.

Q. Is not the upper part of the ilium called the jejunum? A. Decidedly not; the intestine is five times the length of the body - the next intestine to the jejunum is the duodenum, that is the upper one of all next the stomach; that was in a perfectly healthy state, and was full.

Q. Now, would not a kick given between the breasts rather have inflamed the duodenum and jejunum than the ilium? A. But I observed no kick between the breasts that could not have produced the inflammation; if I had found the ilium as I did, and had not heard of what had happened, I should say it arose from external injury received in some way or other - I could come to no other conclusion; I dissected with care to ascertain if there was any hernia.

Q. Might not the same appearances of inflammation have arisen from other causes than violence? A. You make me something beyond human to decide what may be, but from the appearance of the body, I judge it arose from external violence; I examined the body between eleven and twelve o'clock - I was told by a person, whom I had never seen before that, some one had attempted to bleed her some hours after death - but I proceeded to examine the body as surgeon of the parish; the marks on the abdomen were sufficiently plain to see there had been contusions - they were only slight, but the woman dying so early, the appearances would not be so plain as they might be a few days after - they would not be quite so visible at six o'clock; nobody was present but my pupil.
MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Were you informed of the name or address of any medical man who had been there? A. Not at all - if I had I should not have objected to his being present at the opening.

COURT. Q. You confine the cause of death to the inflammation of the ilium? A. Decidedly so; blows, where the contusion was, might have caused the injury on that part - it corresponded with the commencing part of it, but spread both lower and higher; it was certainly connected with the contusion below the navel.

Q. Would inflammation of that sort produce sudden death? A. That depends on the constitution; inflammation increases much quicker with some than others; the appearances I saw might have arisen in four or six hours; inflammatory action proceeds at times very rapidly; dissolution from inflammation is generally sudden; I should have thought she must have felt considerable pain in the abdomen for some hours - death from inflammation sometimes takes place previous to mortification.

DOROTHY LACHMERE
. I saw the deceased after her death, but did not examine her till after Mr. Natorff was gone - I then saw a bruise on her forehead, on her left temple, and a bruise on her left side, between the left breast and hip, and an impression on the hip - this was the moment Mr. Natorff left - when he came he did not know she was dead; there was no other dead body in the house - I was not there when Mr. Tatham saw it.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I am beadle of Poplar. I went to Ralph's, and saw the deceased; I knew her before, and knew her as Mrs. McCarthy - I was present when Mr. Tatham saw the body.
Prisoner's Defence. She never wished me to pay my debts - that was the beginning of my falling out with her on Saturday.
GUILTY of manslaughter only . Aged 41.
Transported for Life .
Before Mr. Justice Bosanquet.

1716.
SAMUEL DRURY
was indicted for
killing and slaying
Thomas Love
.

ROBERT BENNET
. I am a coal-heaver, and live in Keppel-street, Chelsea. On Monday, the 23rd of August , between eight and nine o'clock at night, I was coming from the water side, up Manor-street - I saw Thomas Love coming down the street out of the King's-road, and just before I got into the road, I heard a cart running along the King's-road from Sloane-street, at the rate of between eight and nine miles an hour - it turned the corner into Manor-street
; Love was six or seven yards from the cart, near the side of the cart, about a foot from the pavement - the cart was rather on the off-side; there was room for another to pass on the near side - the prisoner was driving the cart; he turned the corner so quick, it knocked Love down - the horse's shoulder knocked him down, and the wheel went over him; I was about five yards off - nothing was said before he was knocked down; no caution was given - I heard him groaning - I directly ran and laid hold of the horse's head; it had got about six yards, and when I stopped it the prisoner jumped out, and knocked me down - he at first shoved me, and then hit me; I got up, and laid hold of the horse by the hip - a light was procured, and his name and number taken; I then went away - Love was picked up before the prisoner got out of the cart; he did not assist the man, but came over and stood by the side of his cart- I saw nobody else belonging to the cart.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not the prisoner behave in the most savage manner possible? A. Yes, he was more mad than drunk; he never gave the man that was knocked down the slightest assistance - I was quite sober; the man was taken home before the number of the cart was given; the prisoner was not one of the persons who helped him home - he went to the man's house after his cart was let go; I was at the Inquest, but I did not see him there.
COURT. Q. How do you know he did not go home with the man? A. Because I stood with the cart till the man went home; he was taken home before the prisoner jumped out of the cart.

JAMES WILLIAMS
. I am ostler at Mrs. Snow's, Manor-street. I was at the stable door, heard a cart coming round the corner, and then a person call once or twice, after it got round, but I was fifty or sixty yards off, and did not see what happened; I almost instantly heard the poor man groaning dreadfully, by which I suppose the wheel must have been nearly on him at the time I heard the calling out - I went to his assistance; the cart was stopped, and Bennett held the horse's head; I cannot say whether the prisoner had stopped the horse - I and a pot-boy assisted in getting the man off the ground, and in a minute or so a person, who I believe on my oath was the prisoner, came to him and said, "I hope you are not hurt, my friend, (or) you are not hurt" - Love was taken home; I went for a light to take the number of the cart, and did not see who went home with him - I should think the cart was not going at a much less rate than nine miles an hour, which is very fast.

Cross-examined. Q. It was rather a dark night? A. Yes, it was half-past eight or a quarter to nine o'clock - I did not see the cart, but heard it; there were several empty casks in it - the prisoner asked the man in rather a kind manner, if he was hurt; I was behind the cart a considerable distance at the time the witness says he was knocked down.

FRANCIS PRATT
. I am a shoemaker, and live in Queen-street, King's-road. I was going up Manor-street, and heard a horse and cart coming down the King's-road from Sloane-square. I should judge after the rate of eight or nine miles an hour, and all in an instant there was a cry that a man was run over, but I did not see him at all - I went up to the cart - the prisoner then stood alongside the horse; he appeared to me to be drunk - I told him so, and he said, "I always am;" I told him he had better keep a civil tongue in his head - a Policeman came up - I asked him to take the number of the cart, which he at first seemed unwilling to do; I said if he did not I would take his number and letter - he then took it; he was not present at the accident - I told the prisoner it was a serious accident, it was more than probable the man would die, if he was not dead; he said, "What is that to you?" or something of that sort - I never saw the deceased.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose he was taken away while you were talking to the prisoner? A. He was removed a short distance; I have not offered a bet about this trial - I have not offered to bet a bottle of wine, or a sovereign - not to my knowledge; I should not like to swear I have not.

Q. Will you swear you did not offer to Mr. Morrison to bet a bottle of wine that a true bill would be found, and a sovereign that the prisoner would be found guilty? A. I am sure I do not know it to my recollection - I will not swear that I did not; if Mr. Morrison proffered such a bet to me, I might give him an answer, but I was not the offerer of it - I know Morrison, an oilman; I do not think he was summoned in the Coroner's Jury - if I proposed such a bet to him, he first proposed it to me, but I really cannot say any thing about it; I do not recollect any thing of the kind - I believe I saw Morrison at Clerkenwell, and he first proposed it to me I believe; I remember it now - he offered to bet me a bottle, or I never should have offered it; I do not remember that he proposed it - he said something respecting filing the bill; I think be proposed the bet, but should not like to swear it, or that I did not.

JOHN ROTHERY VERNON
. I am not in business - I live in New Manor-street, immediately opposite the spot where the accident occurred. Between eight and nine o'clock I heard the noise of the cart, which was very loud, as if the horse was going very fast - there were a quantity of empty barrels in it, which made a great noise; I was in-doors - I ran out immediately without my hat, as I thought a horse had broken loose; when I got out the man had been run over, and the cart stopped - I saw two or three persons raising the deceased from the ground; I sent for a doctor- the deceased was on the right side of the road, and the right hand of the cart, which was rather on the left of the road, not quite out of its proper side; it is a wide road - it had passed the man a few yards; my impression was, that the cart was going eight or nine miles an hour, but it was stopped before I got out - I went to the deceased's house within a quarter of an hour of the accident, and saw him in bed, in Wellington-street; he expressed himself in great pain - the surgeon was bleeding him, and fomenting his stomach; I saw the prisoner there, and told him his servant had conducted himself in a detrimental way to him as a man of business - when I left the house I pointed the servant out to him; the prisoner then put himself into a pugilistic attitude, and challenged me to fight - he was decidedly in liquor; he told me he was a coal-heaver's mate , and I might go and hang myself.
Cross-examined. Q. Was he not in the room while the man was being bled? A. Yes; he did nothing expressive of any kindness while I was there, on the contrary - I was there about ten minutes.

Q. Did not you begin to abuse the prisoner yourself in such a manner that the widow was obliged to remonstrate with you? A. I did not, on my oath; the surgeon said it was not a proper place for such a conversation, and I withdrew.
COURT. Q. Was that when the prisoner challenged you to fight? A. No; I was telling him of his servant's conduct.

ALFRED BROOK BARNES
. I am a surgeon. I attended the deceased between eight and nine o'clock that evening; his left hip was considerably bruised, which was the only external mark on his body - I did not examine any other part, as he complained of that part only; the injury extended five or six inches - he was suffering a great deal of depression, which is the usual effect of internal injury; I bled him, and applied fermentations - he lived till the Wednesday; the Coroner would not allow me to open the body - I asked permission to do so by the beadle of the parish; it was never opened - there was external injury, but it was impossible to say what caused the death without opening the body; I should say the injury was caused by the cart going over him.

Q. Would that occasion death? A. I should say Yes, but it is impossible to say the extent of the injury without opening the body - as the man was in tolerable health before, and died so soon after, I should say the injury was the cause of his death - it must have been internal injurycaused by the external, no doubt; in my judgment his death was caused by the wheel going over him.

Cross-examined. Q. Can you, as a medical man, venture to swear what was the cause of death without opening the body? A. I have said I could not - I can only speculate on the extent of the internal injury; I have known the spleen ruptured from the blow without any external marks- Mr. Stirling was the Coroner.

Q. Did you not state this to the Coroner? A. He asked if it was absolutely necessary to open the body - I said it was necessary, to examine the exact nature of the accident, but not absolutely necessary to enable me to say he died in consequence of the accident; I have seen one person who burst a blood vessel, without any previous appearance of disease, and which occasioned death, but that was not the case in this instance; I have read and heard of such instances - I once saw a case in which the spleen was ruptured, without any visible external appearance; there are some internal injuries which produce no external marks.

COURT. Q. When had you attended this man before? A. Upwards of twelve months since; he had taken no medicine since as I am told - he was suffering from asthma- that would not cause sudden dissolution.

The prisoner in his Defence, stated, that seeing the deceased near the wheel he had called out to him, and pulled up immediately, but not in time to prevent the accident, and that he had paid him every attention in his power, and carried him home - that Vernon had abused him very much at the deceased's house, and had taken great pains to injure him.

BENJAMIN CULVER
. I am a labourer, and live in Manor-street. I was at my door on the night in question, and heard some one call out - after that I heard a dismal groan; I went, and saw the cart standing still - this was within half a minute of my hearing the call; I saw two persons get out of the cart immediately, and assist the deceased off the ground - I heard one of those persons say, "Send for a doctor;" I afterwards ascertained that to be the prisoner - I saw him afterwards, and was satisfied he was the person; there was not the slightest appearance of the prisoner's being drunk - he rendered the man every assistance; I did not see Bennet for five minutes after the accident - he appeared quite drunk; the deceased had then gone home.
COURT. Q. What is your business? A. I am a gardener; my employers live at Battersea - my brother is a market-gardener there.

GEORGE LOSCOMB
. I am pot-boy at the General Hill public-house, Chelsea. I was passing with my beer about a dozen yards from where the accident happened, and saw the prisoner and another man helping the deceased off the ground - I assisted also: the prisoner helped him all the way home, took him up stairs, and treated him with kindness - I am sure he knocked nobody down; I did not know the prisoner before.

GEORGE TAYLOR
. I am a painter. The prisoner was a stranger to me; I heard the horse and cart going along - it did not appear going fast; I am not a judge of such things, but suppose six or seven miles an hour - it was very dark indeed; I heard the empty casks rattle, which made a great noise - the prisoner and Loscomb both assisted the poor man home; I went all the way - he treated him with great kindness, and was the instigator of the doctor being sent for; there was not the slightest appearance of drunkenness about him - he remained in the room a full hour and held the candle; he appeared very sorry indeed.

WILLIAM BOLTON
. The deceased lodged in my house; Drury and these two men led him home - Drury staid in the room more than an hour and a half, and appeared to treat him with great kindness; he did not appear intoxicated in the least.

SOPHIA LOVE
. I am the deceased's widow. The prisoner assisted him home, and remained in the room nearly an hour and a half - he treated him with kindness and concern, till he was disturbed; my husband in his dying moments said he believed it was an accident - he was afflicted with deafness; he was perfectly sensible he should not get over it - he told me he was like a child when the noise was, and the horse was against his shoulder; instead of running out of the way he most likely ran into it - this was the day before he died; he might have been called to in the road, and not hear.
NOT GUILTY .
It was stated by the widow after the verdict, that she had expressed to the Coroner her desire that the body should not be opened if it could he avoided.

1717.
ELIZABETH HUTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of August , 2 yards of crape, value 2s., and 1 coffee-pot, value 6d. , the goods of
William Silcock
.

There being no evidence against the prisoner but an extorted confession, she was
ACQUITTED .
First London Jury, before Mr. Recorder.

1718.
WILLIAM BRITTON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 7th of June , 1 watch, value 22l.; 2 seals, value 5l.; 1 key, value 2d.; 1 ring, value 20s.; 1 watch-ribbon, value 9d., and 1 watch-guard, value 1s., the goods of
George Toth
, he well knowing the same to have been feloniously stolen .

GEORGE TOTH
. I am a furrier , and live in Wilderness-row, Goswell-street. On the 27th of June, about a quarter to nine o'clock in the morning, I went out, leaving this watch and appendages hanging on a nail - I returned at ten, and it was gone; I had left Charles Wells in the house - he was convicted last Session of the robbery; after his conviction he gave me information, and I went to the prisoner's house in Field-lane; I saw him and said, "Are you a pieman?" he said Yes; I said, "Are you the man who bought a gold watch and two gold seals?" he said,"No, I am a poor man; how could I buy such property? I have not 3s. in my pocket" - I said, "If you are the man, to avoid the trouble of prosecution I would rather give you the money which you gave for the watch;" he said he knew nothing of it; I went home, and in about two days I saw him again in Holborn -
Richard Wells
, my servant's brother, was with me, and in consequence of what he said, I said to the prisoner, "Will you tell me were the watch is? or I'll call an officer;" he said he knew nothing of it - I again said if he did not tell me I would have him taken up - he said, "Well, come home with me, and I will speak with you;" I did not go with him, for there was a row in the street - the people began to push me about; I called an officer, and gave him in charge - I have never seen the watch in his possession,

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. I believe he was takenbefore Alderman Scholey? A. He was taken before an Alderman; he was bailed - I do not know that he was discharged; he came forward voluntarily a fortnight afterwards, when he was told - he was only out of custody once- the Magistrate offered to bail him.

WILLIAM EDMEAD
. I shall be fourteen years old at Christmas. I knew Charles Wells, (who was convicted here) when in Mr. Toth's service; I saw him on Monday morning, the 7th of June, between nine and ten o'clock; he came to my mother's, in St. John's-square-passage, about five minutes' walk from Toth's - he asked me to sell a gold watch for him; I saw it - it had two seals, a key, a guard, a ring, and a green ribbon to it; he carried them in his own pocket - he showed them to me when he came into Benjamin-street; I went with him to Field-lane, and saw the prisoner at his lodgings there - I knew him before; he got his living by buying stolen property, but sold pies up and down Holborn - I took Wells there, and asked the prisoner to buy a gold watch; he asked us to let him see it - Wells showed it to him; he said he did not think it was gold, but he would go and see if it was - he took the watch with him; I followed him to the shop of Mr. Reeves, a pawnbroker - he was asked 3l. for it before he took it there; Wells had said he would ask 2l. - I said, "Don't ask 2l., ask 3l.;" I believed it was gold from what Wells said - I saw the prisoner go into Reeves'; Wells was with me - neither of us went in; he came out and met us at the top of old Fleet-market, gave us 1s., and asked if we were not going to stand something to drink; I never saw the watch after it went into his hands - we went to the first public-house on the righthand side of old Fleet-market from Holborn, and had a quartern of liquor, and a 2d. cake, which came to 6d. - Wells paid for it out of the shilling; the prisoner then went away - Wells and I called in about two hours; he was at home, and gave Wells 8s. 6d. - we asked if he could not give us some more; he said nothing to that, and we came away - we both called again in the evening, and he gave 30s. into Wells' hand; I called alone two days after, and told him that
Charles Wells
was caught - he said, "Never mind, he is sure to get off;" I asked if he could not give me something to take to Wells, and he gave me 7s. 6d. - we went up to where his stall stood, and I tossed him for pies; I won twelve pies for 8d., and then I stood a pint of ale in Fetter-lane - that took 1s. out of the 7s. 6d.; I bought some more things, and took them to Wells - I did not see the prisoner again.

Q. When did you first tell any body of this? was it before or after Wells was tried? A. After Wells told of the prisoner, and I told Sir Peter Laurie at Guildhall - it was about eleven weeks after he bought the watch; I had been taken up then.

Cross-examined. Q. Wells was an acquaintance of yours? A. Yes - I had known him about three years; I have made no agreement with Wells' mother about what I was to say here - I have seen her several times since; I have been in custody, but had no conversation about what I was to say - I told Sir
Peter Laurie
the same, the whole of it; I took Wells in about 6s. worth of things - I kept 1s. 6d. of the money; I did not steal it - I have come from my mother's to-day; I was in the House of Correction for a month; I was never there before, nor in this Court - I was in custody twice; I was eight weeks at Clerkenwell - I have not been in any other place, nor in custody more than twice, except when I was taken up about Wells, but was not in prison; I was never taken into custody for picking pockets - I am to have nothing if the prisoner is convicted; I do not expect to be tried myself if he is not convicted - Wells told of me being one of the party who disposed of the watch; I was in the House of Correction at that time - it was about a fortnight after Wells was convicted; Wells said the prisoner was the person, and I said so too; I did not give information about it till I was accused - I do not know whether the prisoner had the watch in his hand when he went to Reeves; I did not see him take it out of the house, nor did I see him with it at the pawnbroker's - I did not hear Sir
Peter Laurie
say he would not believe a word I said; he offered to bail the prisoner - I went to the prisoner's house about a quarter of an hour after Wells came to me; Wells stopped and looked at it in Benjamin-street, and I saw what was attached to it - one seal was a white stone, and the other a red one; I told the Magistrate so; I do not recollect the colour of the guard.

WILLIAM IVEY
. I am shopman to Mr. Reeve. On the 7th of June the prisoner came to our shop alone - I think it was between two and three o'clock in the afternoon; he came with a gold seal and gold ring, and asked 15s. on them, which I lent him - he pawned them in the name of
John Britton
, Field lane; I have known him six years - on the 8th of June
James Lock
came to look at the seal; he paid the interest on it - I gave him a fresh duplicate; he produced the first one to me - I never saw the prisoner afterwards; on the 11th of June Lock pawned another seal for 12s., and redeemed them both the same day.
Cross-examined. Q. For what was the interest paid? A. One day - I am sure of that; Reeves has another shopman - I cannot state what kind of seals they were.

JAMES LOCK
. I am a waiter at Mr. Low's wine-vaults, Holborn-hill. I have known the prisoner about three years - he offered to sell me the duplicate of a seal and ring for 3s., in pledge at Reeves; I bought it, and took the duplicate to Reeves'; they were shown to me by Ivey- I paid 4d. interest, and had a duplicate in my own name; a few days after, the prisoner brought me another gold seal - I gave him 18s. for it, and pawned it at Reeves' for 12s.; I redeemed them the same day, and delivered them back to the prisoner - he gave me the same for them as I had paid him; he lived in Field-lane - I have not seen them since; I cannot recollect what sort of seals they were - I asked how he came by them; he said he had found them, but did not say where - I saw him several times afterwards, but had no conversation about them; after he had been taken I asked him if there was any fear of my being taken, as I had bought the seals of him - he said No, I had no occasion to come forward to say any thing, for he should appear when his time was up, and he had no doubt he should get through it.

Cross-examined. Q. You cannot state on what day you received them from him? A. No, whether it was June or July exactly; I once pawned my watch atReeves' before, but nothing else; that had common seals to it, not worth 6d. each.
Q. The prisoner said he should get through it - did he not also say he was innocent? A. He did.
COURT. Q. Did he tell you what charge had been made against him? A. Yes, buying a gold watch and seals.

RICHARD WELLS
. I am a journeyman dyer, and live at No. 131, St. John-street. I only know the prisoner by going to him about the watch which my brother had stolen; I went to him when my brother was in Newgate for stealing the watch, after he had been tried - I did not see the prisoner at all; my mother went to him - I was not present; I never heard him say any thing about the watch- I was examined before Sir Peter Laurie, and signed my name to the deposition; I did not take notice whether it was read over to me - I was sworn, and gave an account of what I knew; I never saw the prisoner, or heard him say any thing about it.

BENJAMIN CADMAN
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner on a Sunday afternoon in August - the prosecutor was with me; he was told he had received a watch and appendages - he denied it; he was liberated on his own recognizances - he appeared according to promise, and at the last hearing Sir Peter Laurie desired me to see if I could find any of the property; I went to the pawnbroker's, and found these seals had been pawned.
Cross-examined. Q. What time in August did you take him? A. I think it was on the 3rd; I believe he was allowed a day or two to see if he could find bail.

MR. LEE to
GEORGE TOTH
. Q. I believe you offered this man 6l. to find the watch, and said you would take no proceedings? A. No, I offered him 3l. - he said he knew nothing about it.

GUILTY . Aged 33. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1719.
JOHN WEST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Andrew McKewan
, from his person; and that he had been previously convicted of felony .

ANDREW McKEWAN. I am clerk to a solicitor , and live in Grange-court, Carey-street. On the 6th of September, between eight and nine o'clock in the evening, I was on Blackfriars-bridge
, and am certain my handkerchief was in my inside pocket - my coat was open; I felt something touch my pocket, turned sharp round, and saw the prisoner with my handkerchief in his hand; one or two others were in his company - one between twenty and thirty years old, and the other about sixteen; I am not certain that the taller one was with him - I immediately collared him, and took the handkerchief out of his hand; I kept him in custody till I met an officer - I do not know what became of the others; I am certain of the handkerchief, from its appearance and the pattern.
Prisoner. Q. Are you sure it was me that took it? A. You had it in your hand.

ISAAC EASLEY
. I am a watchman of Blackfriarsbridge. About half-past eight o'clock at night on the 6th of September, the prosecutor delivered the prisoner and handkerchief to me; he charged him with stealing it - he denied the charge; I searched him at the Compter, but found nothing on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. A little boy told me there was a fire at Guildford-street, over the water; I was going over the bridge - two men were on before me, and the handkerchief was thrown right on my breast; I looked at it - the gentleman turned round, and said I had his handkerchief; I gave it him immediately.

JOSEPH ROME
. I have a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office; I am positive the prisoner is the person to whom it alludes; I saw him tried - (read.)

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Life .
NEW COURT. WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 22.
Fourth Middlesex Jury. - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1720.
BRIDGET POLLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 shirt, value 2s. , the goods of
Richard Faulkner
; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 58. -
Confined Two Years .

1721.
JOHN SAVAGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , 1 watch, value 10s.; 1 watch-chain, value 15s., and 1 seal, value 3s. , the goods of
Marin Hatfield
; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Whipped and Discharged.

1722.
WILLIAM SPACKMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 8 half-crowns, 20 shillings, and 4 sixpences , the monies of
William Almond
; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 13. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1723.
MICHAEL LANE
and
MARY LANE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 1 coat, value 18s.; 1 pocket-book, value 6d.; 1 Prayer-book, value 4d., and 1 half-sovereign , the property of
Timothy Lehane
.

TIMOTHY LEHANE
. I had this property in a basket, in my bed-room, at the prisoner's; I put the half-sovereign into the pocket-book at seven o'clock on Saturday, the 7th of August - I went out and came home in an hour or two, and went to get a razor out of the basket; I missed the coat and other articles - I asked for them, but got no answer; I made a great bustle about it, and as I was going out, about ten o'clock, they said they had pawned the coat; I then asked for the other things, and they said I should not have a halfpenny worth of them till I paid them a little balance which I owed them of 11s. 6d.; they did not say what they had done with the things in the pocket.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not you owe them 1l. 1s. 6d.? A. No; there is no such lodger as
Hannah Calley
- I do not know whether I said at first that there was a sovereign; I do not know what I said at first: I never intended to say a sovereign - I went to Cambridge, and had to borrow the money to go; I did not go to a Magistrate, because I was dubious of the law - I went to Hatton-garden, and they told me to give charge of them; the Magistrate let them out on bail - I never told this woman she was welcome to pawn the coat to get some money out of the rent I owed; I meant to pay her at the rate of 1s. 6d. a week when I was in work; she gave me my lodging and my potatoes for dinner when I was out of work - I wrote this agreement, but she has not signed it; I wentand asked for my property - the prisoner and his wife came out, and she said she would throw the boiling water in my face; I suppose there were two hundred people in the street - I came home from Cambridge on the Sunday, and went about this on the Monday; he was taken in two or three days.

COURT. Q. Did they tell you where they had pawned it? A. No - I inquired at several pawnbrokers, but the officer found it; I had paid 5s. that same evening - it was 3s. 6d. for the week, and 1s. 6d. off my debt.

JOSEPH JOHN GOODGE
. I have a coat, pawned by the female prisoner, on the 9th of August.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you known her before? A. Yes, and knew her residence; she gave her own name.

TIMOTHY LEHANE
. This is my coat - the pockets are empty now.

MILES STANLEY
. I took the prisoners - they gave me this Prayer-book, duplicate and letter; they said there was no such thing as a pocket-book or a half-sovereign.
Cross-examined. Q. Then they told you at once about it? A. Yes, and said the man owed them money, and they had pawned it - they were held to bail.
COURT. Q. When did the prosecutor complain to you? A. In September, I think - I went to the prisoners, and they wanted to explain the matter.
Witnesses for the Defence.

ANN KELLY
. On the 8th of August I saw the prosecutor going down the court - he said, "Mrs. Lane, you are very well paid - there was a sovereign in the pocket;" when he came from the country I heard him say, "I am going to take them up for the half-sovereign;" I said,"You ought to stick to the same story;" the Magistrate let the woman out, and he wanted to bring a man to say he had the half-sovereign, but they would not let him - he said, "I have said it was a sovereign, but now I can tell what I like."

MARY EARLY
. I live in the same court as the prisoners do. On the Sunday, when he left their house, I heard him call them different improper names - he said, "You have got the coat and a sovereign;" I went down to Worship-street, and said, "Did not you say it was a sovereign?" he said, "Yes - if there is occasion I can say what I like."
NOT GUILTY .

1724.
ADAM MARSHALL
and
JOHN MARSHALL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , 6 loaves of bread, value 2s. , the goods of
William Fittock
.

MARY FITTOCK
. My husband's name is William - he is master of a Hambro' trader . On the 20th of July I caught John Marshall, who is a soldier , going out of my house in Grafton-street, Soho
, at six o'clock in the morning, with something in a bag - I did not see what was in it, but I gave him in charge of the Policeman; the other prisoner is my journeyman - I keep a baker's-shop: I suspected he had given him the things in the bag.

JOSEPH TILLEY
. I am a tailor, and live in Grafton-street, opposite the prosecutrix's; I saw John Marshall coming out of her house five minutes after six o'clock, with a bundle across his shoulder - she immediately followed him, tapped him on the shoulder, and said, "Now I have caught you in your villiany," and she gave him in charge.

JOHN JULIAN
. I am a Police-officer. I found six 2lbs. loaves in the bag; I showed them to the prosecutrix at the watch-house, and she said they were hers - I went to her house, and she gave me charge of Adam Marshall; he went on his knees, and begged forgiveness - he said he had committed an error, and robbed a good mistress.

Cross-examined by MR. LEE. Q. Did you state this before the Magistrate? A. Yes; Adam handed me 2s.; I did not go into the shop; I went into the bake-house - the prosecutrix said, "John Marshall has taken out six loaves, and this man gave them to him;" I said he had better put on his things and come with me - he said,"I am very sorry, I have taken 2s. of the other man for them; here is the 2s. which the soldier has given me - I know I have committed myself;" he did not say he took the 2s. for the bread.

MRS. FITTOCK. I saw some loaves at the watch-house, but I could not swear they were mine; the price of them was 2s. 0 1/2d., and Adam Marshall laid that money down to pay for them - the Policeman took up the 2s., and said, "Never mind the 1/2d.;" he said he was very sorry he had committed himself that morning; he said he had served the soldier with six 2lbs. loaves, and he had paid him for them - he begged me to forgive him.
Cross-examined. Q. Then the value of them was 2s. 1/2d.? A. Yes; it was taken from the dough-trough, and the soldier was a customer.
COURT. Q. Did the soldier tell you what he had in the bag? A. Yes; he said bread, but he had paid for it.

Adam Marshall's Defence. The soldier was taken in charge before I knew any thing about it; if the woman had come down I should have given her the money - he used to come and have the bread out of the bake-house; I said, "Here is the money for the bread."

John Marshall
's Defence. I am allowed to sell bread, coffee, and other things; I went to the prosecutrix's for bread, and said I would pay for it once a week, but the men did not pay me as I wished, and I went to her, and said I could not pay the bill, but I paid part of it to
Adam Marshall
, and the prosecutrix said she had received it.

MARY FITTOCK
. He always was a customer, and paid very honestly; I had told
Adam Marshall
to let him have bread - I did not wish to go before the Magistrate, but I was forced to go.
NOT GUILTY .

1725.
WILLIAM HUTCHINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 gown, value 2l., and 2 sheets, value 5s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Herring
.

ELIZABETH HERRING
. I am married - my husband is alive; his name is John.
NOT GUILTY .

1726.
TIMOTHY REEDY
was indicted for
stealing, 74lbs. of lead, value 12s. , the goods of
Edward Jones
.

JAMES PERRY
. Mr.
Edward Jones
is contractor for iron pipes to the New River company . I missed a pig of lead from the works on the day in question; I had seen it safe between ten and half-past ten o'clock, at the end of our trench - I have seen it since at Marylebone-office - it belongs either to the New River company or to Mr. Jones; it has N. R. C. on it - they are cast in a mould; it was lead of this description - I have known the prisoner five or six years; I never saw the lead in his possession, or spoke to him about it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How do you know Mr. Jones is contractor to the New River Company? A. I am his brother-in-law; he is considered on his death-bed - the work is now left in my care - I am answerable for every thing; this was missed on the 12th of August - Mr. Jones was then at the New River-head; the prisoner was a deputy turncock - Mr. Jones did not tell me any thing about this piece of lead - I had sent it there that morning; I know he is the contractor.
COURT. Q. Are you foreman there? A. Yes; he buys the lead, and I pay for it.

WILLIAM HENRY
. I am a Policeman. I was on duty in Church-way, St. Pancras, at a quarter past five o'clock in the evening, and saw the prisoner coming along with a piece of lead on his shoulder - I followed him perhaps three hundred yards; I then spoke to him - he said he had found the lead; I said it was false, as it had been evidently cut from some other piece; after some few words, he acknowledged he had got a piece more at home, and if I would go with him he would give it me; I went to take him home, but returned, and took him to our station-house, as he had once behaved rather rough to one of our officers - our superintendent directed me to go to his lodging, where I found his wife and children - I got the key of a little girl who was nursing one of his children: I there found this other piece of lead, and these tools by it, which I presume he cut the lead with.

Cross-examined. Q. Are there any lodgers in the house? A. Yes; I have seen him go into the house, and seen his head out at that window; I was behind him as he came out of his own court with the property - any one might have seen it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was going by and found this lead; I knew the party it belonged to, and thought it might fall out of one of the carts - I was going to take it there when the Policeman met me; I worked for the company upwards of six years, and I thought I would restore it to them.

WILLIAM HENRY
