. He was going from his own house, but not the nearest way to the New-river reservoir.

JURY to
JAMES PERRY
. Q. Where was the trench? A. At Battle-bridge, in the public road - they had not been using lead from the time I saw it till I went to dinner; they did not begin to use lead till two o'clock - a person named Duggin was left in care of the things, and he gave me the information - he might have had his back towards the lead while he was walking about to take care of the tools - I swear positively this is the lead that was missing, by the marks, and there was no other lead there that day; I sent three pigs that morning, and one was taken while we were at dinner.
Cross-examined. Q. Was there not lead missing before? A. Never, to my knowledge; there was a great deal of lead there which belonged to the company.

WILLIAM HENRY
re-examined. Q. Have you stated all that passed between you and him? A. Yes; I am certain he did not say any thing else at all about it.

Q. I have your statement before the Magistrate; did he not say where he was at work? A. No; he told a brother officer that he had it from the gas-works at Battlebridge; he did not say he was at work there - he said it had tumbled out of a cart.
JURY. Q. What time did you go on duty? A. At eight o'clock in the morning; I did not see him go into his house.

GUILTY . Aged 32. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1727.
SAMUEL SHIRLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 1 sovereign, and 10 shillings , the monies of
Robert Honiball
.

ROBERT HONIBALL
. I keep the Reformation public-house, in Long-acre
. On the 21st of August, between four and five o'clock in the morning, I was in bed, heard some one go down stairs very softly, and heard the bar-door open; I got out of bed, and went down after him - I saw the prisoner, who was billetted at the house, at the till, and heard money jink; I was half way down the stairs; he was in the act of shaking a box; when he saw me he came to meet me; I said I had caught him - he begged I would forgive him - I said I would not; I called my son and my servants, but none of them heard; I staid a few minutes, but I was very unwell, and I allowed him to go back to his own bed-room; I called my servants and son again; I went to my own room and dressed - I then went for the Policeman, and gave him in charge - he was searched in about half an hour after I first saw him, but nothing was found on him but a sixpence, and a few halfpence - we never discovered any money on him - he said if I would allow him an hour and a half, he would bring the money that was lost - I missed a sovereign and 10s. out of a box which was in the till.

JOHN HONIBALL
. I am the prosecutor's son - I was in the bar when my sister left at night, but I did not count the money.

JANE HONIBALL
. I am the prosecutor's daughter. I saw the money-box in the till - I saw two sovereigns and about 10s. in it, between twelve and one o'clock - all the family were in bed but myself and brother - there was one sovereign, and about 4s. 6d. left in the till next morning.

WILLIAM HARRIS
. I was sent for to take the prisoner - he said, if we would allow him an hour or an hour and a half, he would go to his brother-in-law's, and make the money good - he asked the prosecutor what he missed - he said, about 30s. he thought - I took him to the station-house, and searched him very strictly, but found nothing on him - I searched the room, but the money has not been found.

Prisoner's Defence. I had to get up early that morning, being one of the guard of honour - I went down, and saw the bar-door open - I was astonished; I looked in, and saw no one; I ventured in, thinking some person had broken in - I had not been there a minute before the prosecutor came and saw me - I told him I had seen the door open - I had gone down to wash.
JURY to JANE HONIBALL. Q. Did you lock the bar? A. Yes; and took the key up with me.

ROBERT HONIBALL. There is a partition on the top of the door, which can be easily opened, but the bottom part was not opened - I afterwards found a knife would open it - he had got over the half door; the till was not locked - I think it was necessary for him to go down to wash, but not to the bar; he seemed to go down softly - I think he had no shoes on.

GUILTY . Aged 34. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1728.
JOSEPH STALLARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of August , 6 live tame geese, price 24s. , the property of
William Nicholls
.

GEORGE NICHOLLS
. I manage the business for my uncle, Mr.
William Nicholls
. I lost six geese on the 22nd of August; I had seen them on the day before - I have seen two geese since, but I cannot swear to them - they were white ones, and ours were all white - they correspond in size - I went to the watch-house, and found the prisoner there, with two geese that morning; he had been employed by my uncle - I have seen him in the stables, the premises are surrounded by a wall six feet high, with spikes at the top.

DENNIS BEALY
. I am in the prosecutor's employ. On the 21st of August, between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, the geese were all safe; there is no fastening to either of the doors of the kitchen where they were; I went out about five or half-past five o'clock in the morning; I found the pond had been dragged for fish, and I saw blood on four separate places at the end of the pond; I have seen the two white geese - one of them has a particular claw, which I had marked, as being one of the two small ones which I had kept back - I had twenty-five of them, and sent them up as they were wanted - they were dead when I saw them.

Cross-examined. Q. What is the mark? A. A hole in the claw - the Magistrate asked how I knew them; I said one had a topping on it; I said so at the watch-house, that I could swear to one of them; I do not know that I was asked about the feet - I went to prove the property; I do not suppose the Magistrate asked me how I knew them - one of the gentlemen asked me some questions - I do not know that I was asked to swear to the geese - I will not swear to the colour.
COURT. Q. What do you mean by saying you would not swear to the colour? A. They were mostly all white.

WILLIAM MASSAM
. I saw the prisoner near Paddington, at five o'clock on Sunday morning, with a basket; I asked what he had - he said a hock of bacon and a bit of bread; I collared him - he said he would go with me, and I let him go; he ran into the canal up to his waist, ran down two hundred yards, and then trampled the basket under his feet in the canal; my brother officer took him, and I got a boat - a person drew the basket out with a stick; I took it to the watch-house, and found in it one small goose and one large one - one with the head off and one on; they were quite warm, and appeared lately killed- I afterwards saw the witness; I do not recollect that he gave me any description of the geese before he saw them - I produce the legs of the geese.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he describe them after he saw them? A. I did not hear him say any thing about them - I asked the prisoner where he brought the basket from; he said from Stone-bridge.

Prisoner. I was at large for six hours. Witness., My brother officer took him to the watch-house, and the inspector sent him back with the officer to find the property - he went into the water to find it, but could not; I went into the boat and got it, and the prisoner walked away - some of the men were to give him a glass of gin; he was taken the same morning.
Cross-examined. Q. Did your brother officer make the slightest attempt to prevent his going? A. No.
JURY. Q. Are you certain it was the same basket? A. Yes - I never left the spot till I found it.

GUILTY . Aged 31. -
Confined Six Months .

1729.
WILLIAM THOROGOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of August , 1 tub, value 2s. , the goods of
James Beal
.

JAMES BEAL
. On the 30th of August, about ten o'clock in the morning, I missed a tub from my shop; I had seen it a quarter of an hour before - a person came and told me of it; I went up the street, as I was directed, and found the prisoner fifty yards off with it.

RICHARD MILLER
. I took charge of the prisoner; the prosecutor took the tub back - the prisoner said he had no tub; at that time the man had it again.
Prisoner's Defence. It was out at the door, and distress drove me to do it.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1730.
WILLIAM WHEELER
and
JOSEPH WARD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 pair of trousers, value 4s. , the goods of
William Mote
and
John Appleford
.

THOMAS HURLEY
. I am a law-writer. I was walking by the shop of Mote and Appleford, and saw Ward walking away with these trousers - the two prisoners were together; Ward first put them under his coat, and then handed them to Wheeler - they were both near the door when Ward took them; they were hanging rather inside the door, and fastened by a string - I did not see them cut down; I told Mr. Pyatt of it, and the prisoners were stopped in Exmouth-street - Wheeler threw the trousers and a pair of scissars away from him; Ward was taken in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour - there was no cry of Stop thief! they ran when the officer was in pursuit.

Wheeler. I was coming from Covent-garden, where I had been to buy some walnuts - he cannot say he saw me at the door. Witness. Yes; I saw him go, and ask the price of a handkerchief - I swear Ward gave you the trousers as you turned the corner.
Ward. He never saw me near the place. Witness. Yes - I am sure he is the person I saw walk away from the shop with the trousers.

MICHAEL RADFORD
. I am an officer. On Wednesday, the 8th of September, a person told me he believed Wheeler had taken a pair of trousers; I crossed, and got within a few yards of him - he had them under his arm; he ran, and threw them down with a pair of scissars - I took him; he said he had picked them up - I asked why he ran; he said he was startled at the time - I took him towards the station, and my brother officer was called to take Ward.

WILLIAM BRYMER PYATT
. I am in the employ of
William Mote
and John Appleford; the witness told me a pair of trousers had been stolen - there is a mark on them; they were on the door-post.(Property produced and sworn to.)

THOMAS MOOR
. I am a constable. I took Ward; I saw Wheeler throw down the trousers - Ward was walking down Coppice-row; the witness said he was the man he saw at the door.
Ward. I was going to Smithfield - I was never in his company at all.

THOMAS HURLEY
. I am quite positive he was the person.
Wheeler. I never ran; I stopped when the officer touched me.

WHEELER -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

WARD -
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

1731.
MARY WATERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 1 counterpane, value 2s., and 2 sheets, value 2s. , the goods of
James Clark
.

LYDIA CLARK
. I am the wife of
James Clark
. The prisoner lodged at our house from October till the beginning of July, when she was taken for robbing us; she had not left the house, but she had not slept at home the night before.

DANIEL BROWN
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner on the prosecutor's complaint; she denied having taken the property - I found the quilt in Laystall-street, not at a pawnbroker's.

GEORGE UNDERWOOD
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned a sheet on the 17th of May, and another on the 28th of June.
The prisoner delivered in a written Defence, stating that poverty had caused her to make use of the property, which the prosecutrix had allowed her to do on a former occasion.
LYDIA CLARK. I never gave her leave to pawn anything at any time.

GUILTY . Aged 30. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged.

1732.
JOHN AGGUS
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 6th of September , of a certain evil disposed person, 12 boxes, value 12s., and 1.800lbs. of tinplates, value 30l., the goods of
John Worrall Grazebrook
, and
George Munro
, well knowing them to have been stolen , against the Statute, &c.
MR. DOWLING conducted the prosecution.

JAMES BROWN. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner; he said he wished me to go to Spicer-street, where he had some boxes of tin, as he had seen in the paper that some had been stolen, and he thought they might be them - he said he had received them from a man in Bethnal-green
, who drew them to the Flower-pot; the man left him there, and he drew them to his own house.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Then he came of his own accord, told you he had the property, and the worthy Magistrate committed him? A. Yes, I have been searching for the other man, but cannot find him.

1733.
JOHN SAMUEL BLAIN
, was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 6th of September , of a certain evil-disposed person, 9 boxes, value 9s., and 600lbs. of tin plates, value 20l., the goods of
John Worrall Grazebrook
, and
George Munro
, well knowing them to have been stolen .
MR. RYLAND conducted the prosecution.

JOHN WORRALL GRAZEBROOK
. I am in partnership with George Munro. In the beginning of this month, we lost a number of tin plates, and on the 7th of September the prisoner called, and said he had a quantity of tin plates, and asked if we would exchange some of them - we said if they were our mark and make, we should have no objection; Mr. Munro asked him if he had any objection to tell who he got them of - he said he had not, but he should not like his name to be mentioned, and he would point out the house of the person he had them from - Mr. Munro said we had lost a great many, and he was suffered to depart; we saw him in custody two days afterwards - we saw the boxes of tin plates.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. There is no doubt they are your property? A. No, the boxes have our marks on them; he took the officer to Aggus' house to show us the man - he was bailed.

JAMES CRANSTONE
. I am clerk to the prosecutors. On the day after he had been to our house, I went with Brown and Attfield to the prisoner's - we said, "We've come about some plates;" he said he had no objection to change plates with us, if we would give him others for them - he said he had bought them cheap, and they were too large; I took them to our place - Attfield asked him if the whole of the premises belonged to him; he said that was not a fair question - Attfield said, "I am an officer, and shall take you if you prevaricate so;" I asked if he had any receipt - he said No; a woman then came, and said she had an entry in a book, but it has no date to it; it states, "Bought nine boxes of tin plates, of Mr. Aggus" - I said if he would go and show us the person he bought them of, we would exchange them; we went to Mr. Aggus', but found nothing there - there was a cart in the place, with the name of J. Aggus, Pott-street, Bethnal-green, on it; a girl said it was her uncle's, and he was gone into the country to buy some pigs - the prisoner said the plates had been paid for in a public-house opposite, that he did not take a receipt, for he was rather tipsey at the time, but there was a person who could prove it - he named the person, but I forget the name.
NOT GUILTY .

1734.
WILLIAM COLLIS
&
JOHN FARRELL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of July , 2 pieces of woollen cloth, containing in length forty yards, value 40l. , the goods of
Thomas William Williamson
.

JAMES GILL
. I am warehouseman to
Thomas William Williamson
. On the 13th of July we gave Collis two cloths to deliver, and an order for two to be brought back; he did not return that day, which caused suspicion - they were to be brought from Mr. Rush's, Bridge-street, Westminster
; he went out about ten o'clock in the morning - I think it was on Tuesday, and I saw him on the Saturday; his father called to say he had got his son, William, back - Collis had been in the prosecutor's employ about two years; I went, and saw him - he said he had obtained the cloths from Mr. Rush, and had by appointment met a boy, named Young; they took a coach, drove to Whitecross-street, and took them to the house of a man named Nathan, where they sold them for 10l. - they were worth upwards of 40l.; I have never seen them since.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Has Mr. Williamson any partner? A. No; no promise or threat was made him that I know of.

THOMAS MOORE
. I am an apprentice to Mr. Rush. Collis brought him the order, and he gave him two pieces of cloth; it was on the 12th or 13th of July - I do not know what day of the week.

MAJOR BUSKIN. I am a hackney-coachman. I was on the stand opposite Adam-street, about two months ago- a youth came and engaged my coach to go to Whitecross-street; I went there with two youths and two pieces of cloth - I cannot swear either of the prisoners were the persons; I took them to the corner of a court - my coach is No. 1200.

JAMES SIVIANE
. I am a butcher, and live at No. 192, Whitecross-street. On the 12th of July I saw the coach No. 1200 drawn up to the corner of a court; Collis took out a large roll of cloth, and a small one attached to it - I did not see any one with him; I followed him, and saw him take them to the second house on the left-hand, where fresh people had come; I went, listened, and heard a conversation in the room - I heard Nathan say, "What do you ask for the cloth?" I had known Nathan before - he had lived up the court; the reply was 40l.: I heard him say he would give 10l. for it - I came out, and met the coachman, who asked me where the lad had gone; I showed him, and then went to my own shop - I then saw Farrell join Collis; they stood opposite my shop, and looked at me - they then went together down Playhouse yard, and the coach went away; I afterwards saw the prisoners return in half an hour or three quarters of an hour, with each of them a bundle in their hands, and new hats on their heads - they went down the court, and came out again, with each a new suit of clothes on.

THOMAS VANN
. I am an officer. I went with Waters to Shrewsbury-court, Whitecross-street, on the 25th of August; we found Farrell there.

THOMAS WATERS
. On the 25th of August I went to the court, and found Farrell; I knocked at the door - his mother asked who was there; I told her, and she said, "I will make you wait till I dress myself;" I went up stairs, and asked if her son was at home - she said No, he slept there sometimes, but was not there then; I found a bed there which was warm; I looked, and found Farrell under his mother's bed, naked.
Two witnesses gave Collis a good character.
COLLIS - GUILTY. Aged 17.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor.

Judgment Respited
.

FARRELL -
NOT GUILTY .

1735.
ELIZABETH FREEMAN
was indicted for
feloniously receiving, on the 7th of September , of a certain evil-disposed person, 4000lbs. of nails, value 78l.; 4500lbs. of tin plates, value 24l., and 17 shovels, value 2l., the goods of
John Worrall Grazebrook
and
George Munro
, well knowing them to have been stolen ; against the Statute, &c.
MR. CLARKSON (on behalf of the prosecution) declined offering any evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1736.
HENRY PECK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July
, 4 sovereigns , the monies of
Isaac Burrows
; and
HENRY TILSON
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen .

ISAAC BURROWS
. I am a broker , and live in Upper Cleveland-street. On the 17th of July I hired a boat, from four o'clock in the morning till eight; I hired it at Westminster-bridge -
Thomas Mellows
and his son were with me; I saw a person laying drunk - I cannot say that it was Tilson - I hired the boat of Peck, and was to pay half a crown for it; he asked for security for it, and I gave him four sovereigns - he said his name was Cook; I said the boat had the name of Sawyer on it - he said it was his, and he had bought it of Sawyer a few days before, and that he would be there to meet us when we came back; I went out, and the boat began to leak - to save myself I took hold of one of the barges, and the boat went off; a waterman came and took me in - my two friends caught another barge, and they were brought back; when we came to the stairs I did not see Peck - I came again at eight o'clock, and staid till nine; he did not come: I gave the boat to the Thames Police, and mentioned the circumstance.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was Peck intoxicated? A. I cannot say - I am positive I was sober- there was a lad named Watts; I do not know whether he was sober - I do not know that I saw Tilson then; Peck was sober enough to stand, and to take my money - he did not deny having taken the sovereigns; I did not nearly upset the boat - we had had a pot of stout and two pots of ale, at Vauxhall, among four of us.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was Tilson the man laying asleep in the boat? A. No; I cannot say whether he was the man laying on the stairs - the man had his face down on his knees; I have not been trying to make any money of any friend of Tilson's - I have received 8l., but I hope I shall be allowed to explain it; since the prisoners were indicted a gentleman called in my neighbourhood, and made inquiries of my neighbours as to my circumstances, and left a card, inviting me to an inn in the City - his name was Waters; I went and saw him, and we got into conversation on this affair, how near I was being drowned - he said he supposed if he were to make me some recompence I should not be above receiving it; I said No, and he said, "Here are 8l.;" since then it has been said it was intended that I should not appear.
COURT. Q. What did you receive the 8l. for? A. I took it to be from some charitable fund - he did not tell me where it came from.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. What were they to give it you for? A. It might be partly for my fright - I did not take it for what I said I had lost, and in lieu of my loss of time. Mr. Mellows was with me.

THOMAS MELLOWS
. I was with the witness, and not in the boat; Peck is the man we had it of - he gave his name Cook; I was on the top of the stairs: my son came up, and said, "This man wants 4l. as security for the boat;" I said, "It is as much as the boat is worth;" I said to Peck, "What is your name?" he said Henry Cook - I said, "How comes the name of Sawyer to be on the boat?" he said, "It is all right - I bought it a few days ago;" when we got to Waterloo-bridge it began to fill with water - we got back; I waited from eight o'clock till twelve, but Peck did not come.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did Peck appear drunk or sober? A. He did not appear drunk - I was not drunk; upon my oath we did not run the boat against a barge, and capsize it - we had been to Vauxhall - as we came over the bridge we had a pot of stout, and some beef and ham in the garden; I cannot swear to Tilson's person - there was a young man named Watts on the top of the stairs; I could not tell whether he was drunk or sober - I did not hear Peck say he would rather accompany us than let us have the boat, unless we returned in an hour; I never received 1s.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you with the prosecutor when he received the eight sovereigns? A. Yes - I do not know what possessed him to think that a charitable fund gave him the money; I understood it was for what he had lost, and the danger he had run.

JONATHAN SAWYER
. I am a boat-builder. I let boats to watermen by the week - I saw this boat at the Thames Police-office; it was not an old boat - I examined it - it appeared to me to have been damaged by being launched; there was a hole which had been patched up with canvas and grease.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do not watermen lend their boats to one another? A. I believe they do allow others to take fares in them; the damage to the boat had been done in launching, not on the water.

WILLIAM WATTS
. I am a waterman. I saw Peck and the gentleman talking, but I did not hear what they said; Peck came up to Tilson, who was lying on his face, and said, "Tilson, here is money;" but I did not hear what it was - Peck then said, "Row the boat to Waterlon-bridge;" I took them there - Peck then offered me a sovereign; I said I would have nothing to do with it - Tilson said, "Take it, it will do you good;" I said, "I will have nothing to do with it;" they took me to Covent-garden, gave me a cup of coffee, a slice of bread and butter, and a glass of gin; I left them at five o'clock, in Bow-street.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. So a sovereign was offered you? A. Yes; I was not sober - Peck was drunk, but not so much as I and Tilson were; I was on the top of the stairs at Westminster-bridge, lacing up my boots; I never was in trouble myself - my master was taken before the Magistrate about some coals, the sweepings of some barges; I went with him - my master had a month at Kingston; I was sent home - I never was in prison; I was taken on this charge by Mr. Little - he said, "Watts, you must step into our boat;" I was examined before the Magistrate - I told the truth.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was not Tilson exceedingly drunk? A. Yes; I could not say he knew what he was about.

ALEXANDER MITCHELL
. I am a Thames Police-surveyor. I took Peck on the Sunday; I found but 6d. on him; he said he had received the money and spent it, and had but 6d. left - he said Tilson had part of it.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was he sober? A. He was half drunk then; I saw Mr. Burrow's about eleven o'clock in the day - he appeared as if he had been either flurried or drinking; I sent Mr. Little after Cook, but he could not find him - Mr. Mellows did not appear drunk.

JOHN LITTLE
. I am a Thames Police-surveyor. I took up Tilson on Sunday, the 18th of July; I said he was wanted for letting out a boat - he said he was asleep on the stairs, that Peck came, awoke him, showed him some money, and gave him part of it, but he was so much in liquor he did not know how much; I asked what became of it - he said they cut his fob, and took 13s. out, which they took to his wife; his wife was present, and she said she had made away with all but two half-crowns.
Peck's Defence. I was very much in liquor, and do not know what I was about - Watt's took a sovereign, and returned it.
Tilson's Defence. I had been drinking.
Peck received a good character.

PECK -
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Confined Fifteen Days .

TILSON -
NOT GUILTY .

1737.
WILLIAM WESLEY
and
THOMAS BROWN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 1 purse, value 3d.; 26 yards of ribbon, value 6s.; 5 handkerchiefs, value 9s.; 3 pairs of gloves, value 2s.; 1 dozen of buttons, value 6d.; 1 purse, value 1s.; 2 sovereigns, 1 crown, 5 half-crowns, 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, and one 10l. Bank note , the property of
John Jones
.

JOHN JONES
. I am a haberdasher , and live in Tottenham-court-road
- Wesley lived with me, and Brown lived in Marylebone-street. On the evening of the 7th of August a Police-officer called, and produced three lengths of ribbon which had my mark on them - I knew them, but I cannot say exactly how lately I had seen them - I went to Mrs. Collier's, where Brown lived; we found Brown, and asked him who he had received them from; he said from Wesley, but did not say when or where - we then found on Brown five silk handkerchiefs, which he said he got from Wesley to take care of for him; we took Brown to the Police station; I went home - Wesley was out; we broke open his box, and found gloves and other things which are mine; when he returned we showed him the things, and asked when he stole them - he gave no answer; the officer searched him, and found 1s. 6d. in his waistcoat pocket - and fastened to his braces was a kid purse of mine, in which was the 10l. note, two sovereigns, and a crown-piece - I gave him into custody; the note is one I had received on the 29th of July, and marked it - it had been in a cash-box in the desk, but the key was left in it; we left him in the shop, making up grosses of buttons, when we went to dinner, and he said he went through the room, saw the key in the desk, and took it out.
Cross-examined by MR. STURGEON. Q. Did you mark the note yourself? A. Yes.

ELIZABETH MARY COLLIER
. Brown was in my employ - Mr. Jones came to my shop about him; some property was found which had been brought to me by a person named Gosling - there were four lengths of black ribbon; I took charge of them for a few minutes, and then sent them out to three different linen-drapers - I asked Brown if they were his - he said Yes, that his mother sent them by mistake with his clothes; I believe these are the ribbons - I gave them to the Policeman, who gave them to Mr. Jones.

JOHN MASON
. I am a Police-officer. I went to take Brown; I questioned him where he got these things - he said from Wesley, to take care of for him; I found these handkerchiefs and these ribbons, and took them to Mr. Jones; Brown refused to tell where Wesley lived, but I found it out - I waited at the prosecutor's till Wesley came home; he acknowledged that he stole these things - I found tied to his braces a leather purse, in which was this 10l. note, two sovereigns, one crown, five half-crowns,and some other silver, which he acknowledged to be Mr. Jones' also.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you hold out any threat or promise to him? A. No.
Brown's Defence. I knew nothing about them - he gave them me to mind for him.

WESLEY -
GUILTY . Aged 13.

BROWN -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

1738.
HENRY LACEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 6 shillings, and the sum of 8d., in copper monies, the monies of
George Abledon
, his master .

GEORGE ABLEDON. I am a baker - the prisoner was in my employ. On the 12th of August he took 6s. 8d. of Mrs. Bailey, of Hackney
; I sent him out with bread that day - she pays on Monday, and had two quartern loaves the week before; there was a little girl in my shop when he returned; I was just opposite - I asked him if he had paid; she said No - he went through into the bake-house: on the 8th of July, I sent him with some bread, which he did not deliver - he had delivered some to Mr. Bailey on the 7th; here are five quartern loaves down in the book on the 8th, but he did not deliver them - he asked for the five loaves, and I delivered them to him.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Did you deliver the five loaves to him? A. Yes, on the Thursday; she never has bread on a Thursday, but he said she wanted eight; there are no names in this book, but he goes to four customers regularly in order, and we know by that who has them; he has entered the five on Thursday - mistakes have occurred with him before; he has come home short of bread sometimes - I thought at first it was a mistake, but afterwards I found he had sold them at 6d. a piece; I am obliged to attend in my shop, as my wife is ill - this young woman comes over an hour or two in the afternoon; the prisoner's book was on the shelf on the Friday where he always puts it - I had looked there before, and it was not there.
COURT. Q. Did you ask on Friday for the money? A. No - I did not expect it till the following week.

SARAH BAILEY
. I am a customer of the prosecutor's; I have bread on the Monday, Wednesday, and Friday - I ordered none on the Thursday; I had paid the prisoner on the Monday; he did no charge for these five loaves - he did not come on the following Monday.

DAVID DEARMAN
. My mistress gave me the money to pay on the morning before, and I paid the prisoner.

THOMAS VANN
. I was sent for to the prosecutor's on the 17th of July; he charged the prisoner with robbing him of fifteen loaves; he said he had left ten at Bailey's, and put the money on the counter - two half-crowns, a shilling, a sixpence, and two pence; he said he knew nothing of the other five, but I said, "Try to recollect who you paid it to;" he said "The young woman was coming from the passage to the shop, and that was the very money I received from Bailey."
Cross-examined. Q. He was in his master's place? A. Yes.

COURT to GEORGE ABLEDON. Q. Did you charge him with fifteen loaves? A. Yes; the ten Mrs. Bailey had the week before, and the five on the 8th - he said he had paid
Martha Bright
for the ten, but I did not ask about the five- I knew she had not had the money; I gave him in charge for having the five loaves, and not delivering them.

Cross-examined. Q. He was still in your service? A. Yes; on the Saturday I sent for the officer - I had not told him before the officer arrived; I keep no books - it is a ready money business; the money is laid down - there is always some person within call to take it.

Prisoner's Defence. My master states he is in the habit of paying attention to his business, but he is always in the Black Boy playing at cards - he is a pugifist; I was in the habit of taking five loaves on Monday, five on Wednesday, and five on Saturday to Mrs. Bailey, and if any other customer wanted them she had to go without till Saturday, as she knows.
NOT GUILTY .

1739.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 1 sovereign, the money of
Richard Payne
, from his person .

RICHARD PAYNE. On the 17th of July I was in Union-street, Hackney-road
, at half-past eleven o'clock in the evening - I had been to a hard week's work, and took a little drop of drink; I had fallen asleep in the street- I had changed a sovereign just before.

WILLIAM SMITH
. I saw the prisoner in the White Bear gardens, at half-past eleven o'clock at night; the prosecutor was lying on the ground, and the prisoner persuaded him to get up, but he would not - there was another row; I went, saw the prisoner go over to the prosecutor, help him up, and they fell down together - the prisoner then got up again, took the sovereign out of the prosecutor's pocket, and put it into his own; he asked me what it was - I said a sovereign; he said it was better in his pocket than in the prosecutor's - he said so help him God he should have it to-morrow; the prosecutor said,"It is all over, it is all over," and then he went away.

WILLIAM HARTGA
. I was going by, and saw the prisoner take something from the prosecutor and put it into his left-hand pocket - the prosecutor said it was all over, and went away; the prisoner said so help him God he would give it him the next morning.

HENRY SOMES
. I am a publican. The prisoner came to change a sovereign with me, and the officer came and took him - he said he had picked it up in the street.

GEORGE COLLYER
. I took the prisoner at the Gentleman and Porter - he offered me the change; I said, "I want the sovereign;" the landlord said, "This is the sovereign" - I made him give the change back; he paid the 1 1/2d. for a glass of gin out of his own money.

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming home, and the good man was laying down asleep, very much in liquor - the two boys were trying to lift him up; I tried to lift him, but could not - I took the sovereign, and said I would keep it till the morning; I told the boys where I had lived for thirty-five years.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 65. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1740.
HENRY MAYHEW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September , 1 clock, value 10s. , the goods of
George Dormer
.

GEORGE DORMER. I am a wheelwright . On the 13thof September I missed this clock when I went home to dinner at one o'clock; it was there at eight when I went out - I have never seen it since; I knew the prisoner, he is a clock-maker , and lived in Somers'-town.

MARGARET DORMER
. I am the prosecutor's daughter. On the 13th of September the prisoner came, and said my father had sent him for the clock - I refused to let him have it; he said my father was at the Black Cap, Camden-town, and he met him for it - I went to the Black Cap - my father was not there; I said he should not take it - he said he would, and in taking it down he tore the pendulum out of my hand and took it away - he gave no reason for it.

JOHN GLEESON
. I took the prisoner. He at first denied all knowledge of it, and then acknowledged he had taken it to another person, who had not returned it.
Prisoner's Defence The prosecutor and I dined together - he gave me orders to go and take his clock, and repair it.
GEORGE DORMER. I never dined with him that day - I had seen him once before, and he repaired it.

GUILTY . Aged 46. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1741.
JAMES SHAW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 9 handkerchiefs, value 1l. , the goods of
Lawrence Kennedy
.

PHILEMON HARVEY
. I am in the service of Mr.
Lawrence Kennedy
- I heard these handkerchiefs were stolen, and went to the door; I saw the prisoner running - I went and took him; these nine handkerchiefs were found in the church-yard, by the side of which he had ran - I had seen them in the morning, and this was between twelve and one o'clock.

JAMES SCOTCHMORE
. On the 14th of August I saw the prisoner running down Cox's-lane, about four doors from the prosecutor's - I did not see him do any thing; I went down the lane, saw the handkerchiefs laying in the church-yard, and picked them up - I saw the prisoner stopped as he was running.

ROBERT STOREY
. I saw the prisoner take off his hat, and heave these handkerchiefs on the ground, not far from the prosecutor's door - I took it up, and was going to give it him, but the prosecutor's young man came out, and I gave it him.

MARY MITCHELL
. I was looking in the prosecutor's shop - I heard something crack, and the prisoner was taking the handkerchiefs from the door - he took them off the nail, and ran; he dropped a yellow silk handkerchief, about ten yards from the door - that was one I saw him take.
Prisoner's Defence. There were a great many people running - I ran, and a sailor stopped me.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 23. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1742.
JOHN THOMPSON
and
EDWARD HUMPHREYS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 1 coral necklace, value 5s., the goods of
Samuel Walter Burgess
, from the person of
Samuel Walter Johnson Burgess
.

JOHANNA BURGESS
. I am the wife of
Samuel Walter Burgess
. My son is two years and two months old, his name is
Samuel Walter Johnson
Burgess - I had a girl to take him out, on the 29th of July, about seven o'clock in the evening, to walk up and down in Canonbury-street
; she came back and said the necklace was lost.

SARAH TUTTON
. I took the little boy out; he had a necklace on his neck - two boy
s took it off, but I did not see it taken; I saw the two prisoners running across the fields together after it was taken.

JOHN BRUNKER
. I saw Thompson go up to the child, and take the necklace; Humphreys was a little further behind, throwing stones at me to keep me back, that I should not go and tell the girl - they then ran away; I went and told her - she went, took the child to her mistress, and then ran after the boys; the necklace has not been found - Humphreys was about half a dozen yards from Thompson, and he said, "One go one way, and the other the other."

JOHN HEBBITT
. I saw the two prisoners; Thompson took the necklace off the child's neck - Humphreys was behind, heaving stones to keep us away; they went down to the bottom of the street, and ran aross the fields - Thompson put the necklace into his pocket.

JOHN SHEPHERD
. I took up the prisoners the next day; they both denied it.
Thompson's Defence. I know nothing about this prisoner.
Humphreys' Defence. I was ill in bed with a sick head-ache.

WILLIAM BAKER
. I am a labourer, and live in Sweetapple-court, Bishopsgate-street. On the 29th of July I came home from my work in the afternoon, about four o'clock; Humphreys was then ill in bed - his mother lodged there; I do not know that he got up afterwards - I was in the one pair, and he was in the bottom floor; I believe it was on a Thursday - I heard from his mother on the Friday night that he was taken up; I did not tell his mother I had seen him on the Thursday.

ELIZABETH HUMPHREYS
. I am the mother of Humpheys, and I will be on my oath that he was very ill in bed on Thursday, the whole day; it was in July - I cannot say the day of the month; I went to work on the Friday, and when I came home, I heard he was taken - my husband is a porter at Mr. Bousfield's; Baker saw my son in bed, and he was remanded to bring witnesses, but I did not consider it would come to any thing - Baker had been out of work, and owes me 9s.; I told him nothing would come of it.

JOHN BRUNKER
re-examined. I had seen Humphreys the day before, and almost every day.

JOHN HEBBITT
. I am sure Humphreys was one of the boys - I had seen him before.

SARAH TUTTON
. I am certain he is the boy; I had seen him for twenty minutes while I was walking with the child.

THOMPSON -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged.

HUMPHREYS -
NOT GUILTY .

1743.
WILLIAM STEVENS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , 1 saw, value 8s.; 2 chisels, value 1s.; 2 brad-awls, value 6d.; 4 gimblets, value 6d., and 3 screw-drivers, value 2s., the goods of
John Field
; 1 saw, value 4s., and 2 chisels, value 1s., the goods of
Samuel Doyle
.

JOHN FIELD
. I am a carpenter . I lost my tools on the 4th of August, from Staples' Inn
, where I was at work - they had been safe at twelve o'clock, and I missed them at half-past twelve.

SAMUEL DOYLE
. I was working at the same place, and lost a saw and two chisels.

WILLIAM HENRY WALSHAM
. Between twelve and one o'clock, on the 4th of August, I was passing Staples' Inn, and saw the prisoner coming across the garden, with a basket; I am a bricklayer, and seeing he was a stranger, I asked what business he had there; he said, a man at the end of the street had sent him for his tools - I asked him to go and show me the man - we went, and he could not find him - he then said, "Pray let me go - I have a wife and seven children;" I said I thought I should not be justified, and took him to the Police.

THOMAS PERRING
. I am a Police-officer, and took the prisoner; he said a man in black gave him 6d. to go and fetch his tools.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I had been where there were some men at work, and a man asked me to go and open a gate, that I should find some tools in a basket under the trees, and he would give me 6d. to bring them down to him; I met this man, who told me to go and put them back, which I did.
Witness. He did not put them down.

GUILTY . Aged 35. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin .

1744.
JAMES TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of June , 1 ass, price 2l. , the property of
William Wilkins
.

MARTHA WILKINS
. I am the wife of
William Wilkins
, he lives at Bedford. I was going to Hornsey, and met the prisoner with an ass - we had lent it to Mr. Smith, at Harpenden
, on the 17th of May - I knew it well - I had driven it hundreds of miles; Mr. Smith was to keep it a month, and in June he sent word he had lost it - the prisoner had it in a cart; I looked at it - he said to me,"You look very hard at it, do you want to buy it?" I said "No - but where did you buy it?" he said, "Of a man named Blake, at Barnet;" I said, "Buy it of who you would, it was stolen from Mr. Smith, and it is mine;" I went to a Policeman, and asked if he knew the man, he said No - but did not notice the name on the cart - I said No, I did not.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you not make any mistake about the ass? A. No, never - I did not describe one which did not turn out to be mine - I described it as a small, genteel black ass - and one was produced which had a white face, and mine was a black one - I have never seen mine since - the one produced was not like mine.
COURT. Q. How long after you lost it did you see it again? A. Not till July.
- DEATH. I live with Mr. Smith - I knew the ass; it was a black one; it was turned out in the grassfield on Saturday night.

WILLIAM HOLT
. I am a Police-officer - the prosecutrix told me about this - I saw the prisoner in the junction-road, the next day, and took him - he said he had sold the ass, but he did not know to whom - she did not say it was hers, but she thought so.
NOT GUILTY .

1745.
LOUISA ELLIOTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 watch, value 30s.; 2 seals, value 2s.; 1 sheet, value 5s.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; and one tablecloth, value 5s. , the goods of
Joseph Bambury
.

The articles being the property of
Sarah Bambury
. the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

1746.
MICHAEL FLING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d. , the the goods of
John Annis
.

JOHN PEEBLES
. I am in the employ of Mr.
John Annis
. On the 10th of July this handkerchief was taken from the door - it was brought to me about six o'clock in the evening; I had seen it safe at two.

GABRIEL BURROWS
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. The prisoner came to me with the handkerchief, and wanted 1s. 6d. or 2s. for it - I think our house is three quarters of a mile from the prosecutor's; I questioned him - he said it was his mother's, and she had bought it at Mr. Mill's, in Kingsland-road; I asked what this was at the corner - he said, "That is where my mother ties up her money;" I then saw some pin-holes, and then said,"Is this where your mother ties up her money?" - I went to the door, and he ran out; I pursued him twenty yards, gave him in charge.
(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress, and received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Confined One Month .

1747.
ANN BECKLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 2 pieces of ribbon, containing 32 yards, value 25s. , the goods of
James Shoolbred
and
Gregory Cook
.

OLIVER DEATH
. I am in the employ of Messrs.
James Shoolbred
and
Gregory Cook
, of Tottenham-court-road
. The prisoner was in their shop on the 31st of August, and a person was sent to tell an officer to stop her; I did not serve her - another person was with her; they were brought back in custody of the officer - I saw the prisoner put her hand into her bosom; I followed her into the counting-house, put my hand into her bosom, and found one piece of ribbon; there are thirty-two yards of ribbon in all.

ELIZA WATTS
. I serve in the shop. This woman and another came in - I attended to them - they asked for ribbons, and I showed them some: they bought a remnant, which amounted to 10d.; it was about a yard and a half - they went out of the shop; I had not suspected them, and did not know why they were brought back; I had not sold them this piece of thirty-two yards - I know the mark on it; I do not know where it was.

WILLIAM BROWN
. I am a Police-officer. I was in Tottenham-court-road, and saw the prisoner and another go into three or four different shops; I had suspicion of them, and followed about twenty yards in the rear, till they got to the prosecutors'; I waited outside, and saw the prisoner put one roll of ribbon into her bosom - while I was there a young man came out, and asked if I suspected any one; I said Yes - the women came out, and I took them into custody; I found this in the prisoner's bosom.

Prisoner's Defence. I never went but into two shops, one to get my bonnet, and another to have a pint of beer; I then went to buy some ribbon, and saw this on a chair - I thought some person had bought it and left it, and I took it up.

GUILTY . Aged 19. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1747.
FRANCIS CRAWFORD
and
ELIZABETH CRAWFORD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 shift, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Leonard Clare Matthews
and
John Matthews
.

LEONARD CLARE MATTHEWS
. I am in partnership with
John Matthews
- we are pawnbrokers
, and live in Whitecross-street
. On the 7th of September the two prisoners came together, to pawn a gown, at half-past eight o'clock in the evening - I saw Elizabeth leave the counter; she seemed to move about; she said to Francis once or twice,

"Go, Jem" - that excited my suspicion; she stood against a partition - I went to serve another person; she then stood against the place where this shift was pinned - I went up, and she was covering this boy with her clothes; he had the shift under his frock.

GEORGE OVERS
. I was on duty - I got this shift from the boy.

Prisoners' Defence (written). I and my brother went with another girl to the shop to pledge some articles, and whilst I was in the shop the girl gave my brother a shift to hold; soon after Mr. Matthews sent for an officer, and gave us in charge.

LEONARD CLARE MATTHEWS
. There was no other girl.

F. CRAWFORD -
GUILTY . Aged 12.

E. CRAWFORD -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Seven Years .

1748.
FRANCIS SKINNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 4s. , the goods of
Walter Berdoe
.

WALTER BERDOE. I was on Clerkenwell-green
, between four and five o'clock, on the 14th of September - I was standing opposite the booth at the election, and felt a hand gently withdrawing itself from my pocket; I turned, and saw the prisoner - he said, "It was not me that did it;" the handkerchiefs was on the ground - there was a mob there: I took him, and gave charge of him - two other silk handkerchiefs were found next his skin, and the duplicate of another.
Prisoner. Q. Can you swear I took it? A. To the best of my belief you did, because no other person, I think, could have taken it, and dropped it there.

Prisoner's Defence. It is a matter of impossibility for him to swear I did it; I was unfortunately next to him - he turned, and asked a gentleman if he saw me do it; the gentleman said No; he said, I did, and took me.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1749.
CATHERINE NAGGS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3rd of September , 1 purse, value 2d.; 1 sovereign, 15 shillings, and 2 sixpences , the property of
Thomas Topp
.

CHARLOTTE TOPP
. I am the wife of Thomas Topp. On the 3rd of September, between ten and eleven o'clock, I was walking along York-street, Westminster
, with my basket - the string of my petticoat broke, and I dropped this purse down - it contained one sovereign and sixteen shillings; a little boy told me the prisoner had picked it up - I went and spoke to her in a potatoe shop; she said,"What does the woman mean?" I told her I understood she had picked up a purse containing my money - I never got it again; it was a dark blue purse - I could swear to it if I saw it; I cannot tell how near she was to me when I dropped it.

JOHN BARRON
. I am going on for nine years of age; I saw the prosecutrix and the prisoner there - I saw the purse drop a little way from the gutter - the prisoner took it up, and put it into her apron; the prosecutrix was six or seven doors off - I went and asked her if she had dropped any thing; the purse was near the colour of my hat - the prisoner put it into her apron.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not accuse a woman who had a dark blue gown on? A. No.

FREDERICK KINGSTON
. I live with a pawnbroker. The prisoner redeemed several articles from his shop on the day in question, and paid me a sovereign; I had known her before.

Prisoner's Defence. I had left my house at half-past nine o'clock; I went to the pawnbroker's, and took a half-sovereign, not a sovereign - I got a few things out for my child - this woman asked me if I had picked up a purse; I said No; the lad then said the woman was like me, but not me, she had a blue gown on.
NOT GUILTY .

1750.
HENRY MILLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July 1 copper, value 15s., the goods of
William Wyatt Grainge
, fixed to a building of his .

THOMAS CROKETT
. I am headborough of Hillingdon. On the 31st of July, I was in Mr. Benham's shop, and ironmonger, at Uxbridge
, and
David Lane
brought in this copper for sale - Mr. Benham refused to buy it, and said he had better take it to Mr. Grainge; instead of which he made the best of his way down Page's-lane - a gentleman told me I had better go after him; I went and saw the prisoner with it on his shoulder, and Lane with him - they ran off; the prisoner threw down the copper and ran through a river - I pursued the other, but lost him in a bean-field; this was about a quarter of a mile from the prosecutor's - I fitted this copper to the place; it matches exactly; the prisoner is a native of Uxbridge.

THOMAS WILLIAM GRAINGE
. This copper is my father's,
William Wyatt Grainge
- it was in a house which the tenant had left; I did not see it fitted to the place - it had been safe on the 19th of July; the window was broken- I cannot say when it was taken.
Prisoner's Defence. I saw Lane, who asked me to carry it for him, which I did.

GUILTY . Aged 22 -
Transported for Seven Years .

1751.
WILLIAM JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , 1 pair of trousers, value 9s. , the goods of
John Matthews
and
Leonard Clare Matthews
.

THOMAS BLEWETT. I am in the service of
John Matthews
and
Leonard Clare
Matthews - they are pawnbroker
s, and live in Whitecross-street
. On the 11th of September the prisoner, who was a stranger, came and took the trousers from their door, and ran up Long'sbuildings; I pursued him through Blue Anchor-alley, and then gave an alarm - he got over a wall; I lost sight of him - he was taken in about ten minutes; I am positive he is the man - he dropped them from under his coat, and I caught them in my own hands.

JOHN BONE
. I am a labourer. I heard the cry of Stop thief! I ran out, and saw the witness in pursuit of theprisoner; he turned into a court which is no thoroughfare, went into a house, and got over a wall, eight or ten feet high - I went into the next house, and saw him get over a second wall; I pursued him - he went up to the first floor of a house, and I took him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I have a wife and family.

GUILTY . Aged 46. -
Confined Three Months .

1752.
JOHN JACKSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September 1 jacket, value 5s. , the goods of
John Gage
.

JOHN GAGE
. On the 7th of September I went on board the Emerald, in the West India-dock bason
, to work as a labourer - I pulled off my jacket, waistcoat, and trousers, and put them on a chest at eight o'clock; at twelve o'clock the steward came, and asked me if I had any clothes - I ran on shore, and told the officer to stop the prisoner; he had my jacket on and the trousers, the waistcoat was in his hat; he had been at work on board that ship.

JOHN BISHOP
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner come on shore from that ship; the prosecutor spoke to me - I stopped the prisoner; the prosecutor said that was his jacket and trousers - I took the prisoner in the office, and asked if he had any thing in his hat; he said No; I took off his hat, and found this waistcoat in it.
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY. Aged 60.

Recommended to Mercy -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1753.
JAMES GREEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , 6 shillings , the monies of
Mary Dickerson
.

MARY DICKERSON. I keep a shop at Tottenham
. On the 15th of September the prisoner came in, said he had the tooth-ache, and asked me to give him a bit of ginger - I gave it him; he went out immediately - a person came in, and said a boy had run out of my shop; I had had a bowl in my till, with 6s. or 8s. in it; I looked, and missed it all - I went in pursuit of the prisoner, who was taken the same evening; the officer brought him and the money to me.

ANN SPENCER
. I live near Tottenham church. I saw the prisoner run out of the shop - I had not known him before, but I am sure he is the same boy; he kicked my legs - I told the prosecutrix a ragged boy ran out of her shop: she looked, and missed the money.

JOHN HUMPHREY
. I was informed the prosecutrix had lost the money: I suspected the prisoner, whom I had seen lurking about - I saw him in Love-lane; he saw me, and ran - there were some boys before me; I called to them to stop him - a little boy ran after him; he ran round to very near the street; I came up, and he ran into some woods - I asked him for the money; he said he had given it to the little boy, who gave me 6s.

EDWARD GRAY
. I pursued the prisoner - he said,"Little boy, let me go," and gave me the 6s.
GUILTY. Aged 9.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor .
Whipped and Discharged.

1754.
JOSEPH GORDON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , 1 coat, value 7s. , the goods of
George Livesley
.

GEORGE LIVESLEY. I lost my coat on the 15th of September - the prisoner lodged in the same room with me, at No. 34. Belton-street, Long-acre
- I have seen my coat since; I never permitted him to pawn my clothes - I have known him from eight to nine months.

WILLIAM HUMPHREYS
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at No. 66, Long-acre. I have a coat, but I cannot say who pawned it - I gave this duplicate for it.

EDMUND LARKIN
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner - in going along he acknowledged to the prosecutor that he took the coat, and pawned it in Long-acre; in consequence of which we found it - this is the duplicate he described.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I did not know what I was saying - the next morning the officer said I had confessed; I was quite intoxicated.
GUILTY. Aged 21.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

1755.
JOHN EADES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of August , part of a gold chain, value 6s.; 1 seal, value 2s., and 1 key, value 1s., the goods of
John Limbert
, from his person .

JOHN LIMBERT. I am a grocer , and live in Tottenham-court-road. On the 9th of August I was in Oxford-street
, opposite Harewood-place, leading to Hanover-square, about eleven o'clock at night; I was walking home, and was quite sober - the prisoner came to me, and snatched my chain and seals; I collared him, and took hold of his hand - I got the chain, which he had broken off, and the seals from his hand; there were two or three more about - he got away, and ran down Harewood-place; I pursued, and a Policeman stopped him.

Cross-examined by MR. CHURCHILL. Q. Was there not a large quantity of people? A. No, not large - I did not lose sight of him; I never expressed a doubt about his person - I did not give him a good thrashing.

JOSEPH FREDERICK CLEMENTS
. I am an inspector of Police. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house, and this property was brought in by the prosecutor; I found two skeleton-keys on the prisoner.
Cross-examined. Q. What did he say of them? A. He said one was his street door key, but did not give me his direction.

Prisoner's Defence. I had not removed more than three days - my landlord's goods were seized, and I moved opposite; I went to get some keys at Mr. Cox's, and he lent me one to fit the door while he made one - there is no skeleton-key among them; this is the key I had made, and this one I borrowed.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Life .

1756.
FLORENCE CRAWLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Stephen Hart
, from his person .

STEPHEN HART. I am out of business. On the 28th of August I was in Wilson-street, Finsbury
, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon; I felt my handkerchief drawing from my pocket; I turned, and saw the prisoner running away - I pursued; a constable stopped him, andtook this handkerchief from him, which is mine; I did not see who took it from me.

THOMAS SAUNDERS
. I was coming from Finsbury-square, and heard Stop thief! called I saw the prisoner running, and putting something under his coat - I pursued him; he ran up the City stone-yard - I ran up, and took him: I looked under his waistcoat, and found this handkerchief.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I had been some time out of employ; I saw this handkerchief down by the gentleman's heels - I put it into my bosom, and the gentleman turned and cried Stop thief! I ran, and was taken.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1757.
JOHN BATTEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August , 1 fork, value 2s.; 1 dibber, value 1s., and 1 pair of barrow straps, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Deadman
.

THOMAS DEADMAN
. I live at Hammersmith
, and am a market-gardener
. The prisoner had worked for me at different times about two months previous to the 26th of August; when he was gone, I missed a great many tools - he had been a labourer; I found him at work for a neighbour, where he had to find his own tools - I found him going from one garden to another, with a pair of barrow straps of mine; he turned round, and tried to escape - I followed him, and took the straps from him; he was locked up - I went to where he had been at work, and found this fork and dibber.

JOHN SPOONER
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner.

REUBEN MARTIN
. The prisoner was working for my father, and had this fork and dibber; I have known him three or four years - I never heard any thing bad of him.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked up the straps going along Brook-green, looking for work - the fork and dibber I bought for 3s.
GUILTY. Aged 35.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Fined 1s. , and Discharged.

1758.
ELIZA WRIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 gown, value 5s. , the goods of
Edward Baylis
.

HENRY SUTTON
. I am in the service of Mr. Chapman, a pawnbroker, in London-street, Fitzroy-square. On the 2nd of September I saw the prisoner looking at some gowns at our shop; I saw her attempt to take one down - she saw me, and left it; in about an hour or an hour and a half she brought this gown in, and offered to pawn it for 4s. - she said it was her mother's; I asked where she bought it - she said of Mr. Baylis, in Hampstead-road; she then ran out, and a young man brought her back - I went to Mr. Baylis', and they said they had lost it.

HENRY LINDER
. I am in the employ of
Edward Baylis
. This gown is his property, and was taken from his door, at No. 8, Adam-row
, about ten minutes' walk from the witness'; I had not seen the prisoner there - it has our private mark on it.

GUILTY. Aged 14. -
Judgment Respited
.

1759.
STEPHEN WILFORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 pig, price 5l. , the property of
William Brown
.

DAWSON LUCAS
. I am an out-pensioner of the 66th regiment, and live at Chelsea. On the 2nd of September I met the prisoner coming out of Chelsea at half-past ten o'clock in the morning, driving a pig - I suppose it was three-quarters of a mile from Mr. Brown's; it was a very large sow; the road was newly covered with flint stones, and her belly hung on the stones; I said to him, "Drive her on the side and then she can't injure;" I went on and met Mr. Brown, who said he had stolen it - I thought it was a joke, and I said, "That won't do;" I went on about ten yards further, and met another man - he asked if I had seen a man driving a pig; I said Yes; he said, "He has stolen it;" I turned and followed him - the prisoner took the first turning, they went down the second; I took the same turning as the prisoner did - he went on to some buildings where there were boards projecting from the area; he got over the boards and dropped down fifteen feet; I followed him - there were a number of men who said he was in this room and that room, and the cellar - I lost him, but was on the look out for him for some days, when I saw him looking over the curtain of a lower room; I got an officer, we could not get in - the officer broke the door open and took him; he asked what he had done - he said it was on a charge of felony; he said, "My father sent for me, and told me all about it - it is for stealing a pig."

WILLIAM BROWN
. I am a butcher , and live at Chelsea
. I lost the sow from a little bit of grass where I had turned her to graze - I heard she was gone, and pursued her; I met this witness - the prisoner turned down a turning, and I went down the next turning; he took up two or three stones to throw at the sow, and turned to see if any body was watching him - we lost him in the buildings; I had not seen him before - he left the sow, and I took it.

JAMES LAMPORT
. I am a sawyer. I saw the sow turned into Mr. Handford's field; the prisoner drove it into the King's-road - I told Mr. Brown about it; we went and overtook him - he was lost in the buildings, and left the sow.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Confined Six Months .

1760.
JOHN THORNS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22nd of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Thomas Dunne
, from his person .

THOMAS DUNNE. I am assistant to a linen-draper . I was in St. James-park
, about the middle of the day, on the 22nd of July; I had a handkerchief in my pocket - I did not feel it taken, but a person told me I had lost it; I turned, and searched my pocket - a person seized the prisoner, and said he was the person who took it - my handkerchief was found on him; it was given to the Policeman, who has since been discharged, and I have not heard of it since - I swore to it at Queen-square.

GEORGE DORRELL
. I was at the review that day - I saw the prisoner pick two people's pockets, and then the prosecutor's; I endeavoured to reach each of the other gentlemen, but I could not; the prisoner was taken with the prosecutor's handkerchief, and six others.
Prisoner's Defence. When I was taken to the office, he said he never saw me near the gentleman.

GUILTY . Aged 20. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1761.
MATILDA SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 3 sovereigns; one 10l. bank note,and one 10l. Bank post-bill, the property of
Ellis Stockbridge
, from his person .

ELLIS STOCKBRIDGE
. I came from Melbourn, in Cambridgeshire. On the 7th of September I was at Hadley, near Barnet
; at half-past seven o'clock in the evening, I met with the prisoner, as I was going to take the gate off a field, in which were four horses, which I had to take from that fair to Harley-bush - I had not known the prisoner before - I had two 10l. notes, five sovereigns, a crooked 6d., and a pearl button, in my purse, in my watch-pocket - I had no watch; the prisoner and I were talking together some little time - there was another girl with her, one was on one side, and the other on the other; we had been together five or ten minutes; I gave the prisoner 1s. out of another pocket - not the one my purse was in - I turned into another footpath, near the Magistrate's house, and then missed my money - the other girl had then nearly turned from me; I told the prisoner she had picked my pocket; she gave me my purse, and said, there was my money - I said it was not right; I took it into a shop, and found the notes, the button, and crooked 6d., in it, but the sovereigns had been taken out, and five farthings put in instead of them; I still kept hold of the prisoner; I left my purse at the shop, and took her to her lodging; where she said she could find the person who had them; when we got there, she wished me to take her things while she went and got the money - I said they were of no use to me; I then went with her to Barnet, in search of the other girl - we went into a public-house, and there made inquiries for her, but in the room of her coming, seven or eight fellows came and tried to rush her away - I got her into a booth, and gave charge of her - I have never found the other girl, nor the sovereigns.
COURT. Q. How did she get it? A. I do not know; I did not unbutton my breeches - I had the purse in my hand, going down Barnet.
Prisoner. I said I would make the money good, because he frightened me so much; I would have parted with the last stitch of clothes I had to do it.

JOSEPH RICHES
. I am a grocer, and live at Hadley. Between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, the prosecutor brought the prisoner to my shop, and accused him of the robbery; I saw the two 10l. notes and the purse in his hand, and five farthings, instead of sovereigns; she said she would make them good.
WILLIAM HARRIS. I took the prisoner; this is the purse.
ELLIS STOCKBRIDGE, This is my purse, sixpence, button, and notes.
Prisoner's Defence. He said he had lost his purse; I stooped down, and picked it up from the side of his foot- I said, "Here is your purse;" I believe he threw it down of his own accord.

GUILTY . Aged 21. -
Transported for Life .
OLD COURT. THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 23.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1762.
WILLIAM HINE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of July , 10 gowns, value 10s.; 8 shifts, value 15s.; 7 petticoats, value 7s.; 9 caps, value 4s.; 5 aprons, value 2s.; 4 pairs of stockings, value 4s.; 8 yards of Irish linen, value 6s.; 11 frocks, value 5s.; 1 pair of stays, value 2s.; 1 table-cloth, value 2s.; 9 napkins, value 2s.; 2 pillow-cases, value 1s.; 9 pillows, value 16s., and 5 shoemakers' tools, value 3s. , the goods of
Charles Hitchcock
.

CHARLES HITCHCOCK. I live in King-square, Wilson-street
, and am a shoemaker . The prisoner took a lodging of me on the 19th of April as a single man; on Saturday, the 24th of July, I went out about half-past seven o'clock in the evening, returned after eleven, and found my little boy waiting at the door - I had left my wife at home in care of the house, and all this property secure - I occupy one room below, and work in the prisoner's room; this property was chiefly in the bottom room; I have four children by my wife - the eldest is seventeen years old - he was out at the time - my youngest is two years old; I inquired for my wife, and found she was gone, and the prisoner also - the prisoner's week was up on the Monday - he would have been indebted to me about 18s.; I found my place quite deserted, the drawers and every thing stripped; I went up stairs and all my things were gone - my working tools were taken off my bench up stairs; a great deal of the property is my wife's dress; but there was table-linen, pillow-cases, and five or six shoemaker's tools, which were all safe when I left, and the prisoner was then in the workroom - he had not said he was going; I could have placed my life in his hands - my wife had taken two of the children away, I could not find them; I got information from a coachman, and found her at No. 17, Penny's-fields, Poplar, on the 17th with the prisoner and children, and all the property except the bed-tick, which was in pawn - my wife came home that evening, and we have been living together ever since; she had 3l. when she went away.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You and she had some disagreement had not you? A. We had a few words through the prisoner poisoning her mind that I was cohabiting with a woman.

Q. I am told you went to France and left her pennyless? A. I went, with her consent, for three months, to see if I could do better than here - that was sixteen years ago; the prisoner has poisoned her mind under the cloak of Religion - the apparel belonged to her and the two children: he had tools of his own, but these were mine.

JOHN NEAL
. I am a hackney-coachman. On the 24th of July, at ten o'clock at night, the prisoner came and asked what I would charge him to go to Poplar, near Limehouse-road - I said 5s.; he said if I was not gone off the stand in a quarter of an hour, he would take me - he brought a woman and two children; they got into the coach, he got on the box, and drove to Philip-lane, close by; several bundles were put into the coach there - I drove them to Poplar, and put them down at Penny's-field; the prisoner paid me 5s.

Cross-examined. Q. It was quite dark? A. Yes - I never saw the prisoner before; I am sure he is the man - I saw him take the goods out of the coach; I did not see him use any compulsion to the woman; the goods were not taken from the prosecutor's house.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. The tools the woman was capable of using herself - they were not taken for my benefit, but for her use; I wish her to be called.

ELIZABETH HITCHCOCK
. I went away with the prisoner by his enticement; I did not give him the goods - he pawned the bed-tick; he took the goods away to Philip-lane - I did not know where he was going to take them; he did not take them by my direction.

GUILTY . Aged 28. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1783.
JOHN WILLIAM GRINDLE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 seal, value 7s.; 1 key, value 3s., and 1 pair of overalls, value 7s. , the goods of
George Allen
.

GEORGE ALLEN. I am groom to Captain Osborne; the prisoner is a groom , and lodged in the same house with me for about two months - he told me he owed a horse-dealer some money, and was compelled to pay it, but he had not enough; he asked me to lend him some - I said I could not, but would let him have my watch to deposit with the ostler - I went with him, and saw the ostler's wife receive the watch; he was to bring it back to me immediately it was returned - I never permitted him to pawn it; I went to his master's stables to assist him, and left my jacket and overalls in the room over the stables: I had not lent them to him.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not give me these things? A. Never; I did not authorize you to pawn any thing - I never pawned the watch myself; I asked him where the duplicates were - he said he had left them at a coffee-shop for 3s.; I gave him 3s. to get them - he returned, and said the man was not at home; I slept with you one or two nights, but you did not support me - you gave me a breakfast when I helped you work.

JOHN BALLAM
. I am a pawnbroker, of Marylebone. I have a silver watch pawned, in the name of Green - I did not take it in; I have a pair of trousers and a jacket, pawned by a groom, but it was not the prisoner.

RICHARD HARTLEY WALL
. I apprehended the prisoner. He told Allen he would show him where the duplicates were - he took us to a green-shop, where we found the one for the watch, and the other at another place, which he directed me to.

THOMAS KNIGHT
. I am a coffee-house keeper. I lent the prisoner 5s. on this duplicate the morning he was apprehended.
Prisoner's Defence. He gave me leave to pawn the watch.
NOT GUILTY .

1784.
JOHN WILLIAM GRINDLE
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 pair of breeches, value 12s., and 1 pair of overalls, value 5s. , the goods of
Benjamin Jones
.

BENJAMIN JONES
. I am a groom out of place . The prisoner allowed me to sleep with him over the stables of Mr. Dyer, High-street, Marylebone
- I slept there off and on for about five weeks. On the 31st of July, we agreed to go together to a free-and-easy; when we got to the gate, the prisoner went back - I waited for him; we then went on together - he went into Flemings', a pawnbroker, to pawn a coat which he had with him; I waited outside for him - we went to the club; I left him in the Strand - I got to the room between two and three o'clock in the morning; I found my jacket, and three or four handkerchiefs laying down in the yard, and some of the prisoner's things - I went into the room, found the window open, and missed the watch and some blacking brushes; I told him of my loss when he came in - he appeared sorry for it, but never said he knew any thing about it; I asked him to take a pair of overalls home for me, and found them in pawn - when I asked him for them he said Mr. Dyer's footman was going to buy them; I found my watch in pawn on the 16th of August.

Prisoner. Q. When did I come in? A. Not till ten o'clock in the morning; I had left the room locked, and the window shut; the carriage would not allow the coach-house doors to close - nothing of yours was gone but a pair of boots; the Policeman had told me he had seen some suspicious persons about there, a few days before.

EDWARD O'NEAL
. I keep a jeweller's-shop in High-street. On Monday, the 3rd of August, the prisoner came and offered the ticket of a watch for sale; I said I would look at it if he would call in the evening - I made inquiry, and found it was stolen.

HENRY WILLIAM PARR
. I am shopman to Mr. Fleming. I produce a watch, pawned on Saturday, the 31st of July - I did not take it in; the duplicate produced is what was given for it.

JAMES MOODY. I am a pawnbroker, of East-street. I have a pair of overalls, and a handkerchief - I cannot say who pawned them; they are in the names of Ox and Walker - these are the duplicates which were given for them.

RICHARD HARTLEY WALL
. Knight gave me these duplicates; he got them from the prisoner.

JOHN BALLAM
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a pair of boots, which were pawned; I do not know who by - here is the counter-duplicate of them.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I supported these young men while out of situations, and paid at the free-and-easys for what they drank - I distressed myself for them, and all their property was given into my charge, to do what I thought proper with; I bought the duplicate of the watch of a young man who was in distress; I offered it to the witness, who I knew was acquainted with Jones.

BENJAMIN JONES
. I never knew the jeweller before.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Transported for Seven Years .
Before Mr. Recorder.

1785.
THOMAS CHITTELL
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Wood
, on the 31st of August
, and stealing, 8 sovereigns, 2 half-sovereigns, 4 half-crowns, and 10 shillings, his monies ; and
JOHN PUTTICK
,
GEORGE BULMER
, and
DANIEL WARD
were indicted for
feloniously receiving the said 4 sovereigns, well knowing them to have been stolen .

THOMAS WOOD
. On the 31st of August I lived in Syer's-buildings, Mill-wall, Poplar
; my son James is the tenant - I lived there by his permission, but paid no rent: he does not live there now; he left the day before this happened, his term having expired as soon as he could pay the rent - he left the goods there till he could pay the rent; he only took the house from week to week - he lives at Greenwich; I was not in his employ at all - his goods were left in the room in which I dwell till he could paythe rent; he never intended to return to the house again. I went out, between five and six o'clock in the morning, on the 31st of August, leaving this money in my trunk in the back kitchen; I barred the back door leading to the back kitchen, and locked the front door - I returned between six and seven o'clock in the evening: I found the back door broken open - my trunk was broken open, and the money gone; Chittell lived next door but one to me - he was taken up four or five days after.

Cross-examined by MR. RYLAND. Q. When had you seen the money? A. I recollect counting it the night before this happened, and put it into a little box, under my clothes in the trunk, which was locked, and I had the key; I did not go out till the Tuesday morning - I found a pane of glass broken out of the back window; the money was all my own.

THOMAS PARSLOW
. I am a Police-officer.
