I met the prosecutor with a young man, who asked me to go with him; I got on to Milbank, and he was so very obstinate I was forced to leave him - I went on and found the hat; I took off my cap, and put it on; I met the officer, who said he must detain me - the gentleman then came up without his hat, and said he had no knowledge of me, and I had not robbed him.

JOHN TUBB
. Immediately I brought up the prisoner, the prosecutor said, "That is the fellow (or) the villain who took my hat."
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 20.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined One Month .

1815.
THOMAS SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , 1 sovereign, and one 5l. Bank note, the property of
Robert Mitchell
, from his person .

ROBERT MITCHELL
. I am a sailor . On the 15th of September I was lying on a bed in a house in Albion-street, Commercial-road
- I had been paid at the India-house, and was rather intoxicated; the prisoner was with me at the India-house - he was not in the room when I lost my property, but was under the same roof; the sovereign was in my right-hand trousers pocket, and the note in the other; I have not seen the note since - I have seen a sovereign, but could not swear to it; there was a girl lying behind me, but not asleep - she awoke me, and told me of it.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What time was this? A. I was a little intoxicated; I think it must have been between seven o'clock and ten - I was not so drunk I could not stand up; the woman was not drunk; I called an officer, and gave her into custody with two men - there was a person named Hardy there; I think I had been in three public-houses after I received my money - I will not swear I had not been in six; I had but one girl with me; there were three other girls in company; I had been twelve or thirteen days living at the prisoner's house, and owed him money, which I intended to pay when I got up; I owed him a bill of 6l. 12s. - it is still due to him; no one was in the room with me but the girl - I found the prisoner in the passage, and Hardy with him; I gave the girl in charge, and then then the two men as fast as I could speak - after the girl was in custody she said the prisoner had it; I do not remember seeing any money fall - I heard a woman say to the girl, "If you have got the money why don't you give it to him?" the girl was crying, and said she had not - she did not say she bad money, but not mine - this was in the room; I remember her going on her knees, and protesting she had not the money.

HARRIET CLEVER
. I was living with the prosecutor at the prisoner's house - he came from the India-house, and said he had a 5l. note and a sovereign; he went on the bed to lay down with me between four and five o'clock; the prisoner asked him to pay him - he said he would as soon as he got sober; the prisoner then left the room, and came in a little afterwards, while the prosecutor was asleep, and felt in his left pocket, took a pocket-book out, and a paper out of it - he then felt in his right-hand pocket, and took out a sovereign.
NOT GUILTY .

1816.
DENNIS SULLIVAN
and
JOHN KIRBY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 2 iron gratings, value 3l., and 1 iron frame, value 2l., the goods of
Christopher Richardson
the elder, and others, the
Trustees and Commissioners of a certain Turnpike-road, there called the Commercial-road
.

2nd COUNT, stating the goods to be the property of
Christopher Richardson
.
3rd COUNT, stating the goods to be the conveniences belonging to the said road.
FIVE OTHER COUNTS, varying the charge.
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

JAMES BARNES
. I am contractor for excavating the Commercial-road. I saw some grating and frames lying near Green Arbour-square
, at six o'clock in the morning, on the 10th of September, that belonged to Mr. Richardson and the other Commissioner s - Sullivan worked for Mr. Rutter.

JOHN COLLINS
. I am a wheelwright, and live in Little Turner-street, in the Commercial-road. Sullivan came to my house last Friday week, about two or three o'clock, and said he wanted a truck to move some sailor's things from the Halfway-house to Church-lane; I let it him - I found it again at the Flying Horse-yard near the office.

MATTHEW SKIPP
. I deal in iron, and live in Church-lane, Commercial-road. Last Friday week I saw the two prisoners between four and five o'clock - they brought two iron gratings and one iron curb in a truck; Sullivan offered it for sale - I asked where they got it; he said he came from Mr. Robertson, the builder, at the back of the hospital - I said, "Why does not Mr. Robertson send a note that I might know who it came from?" Sullivan said I had no occasion to be afraid - I said I would know whose it was before I bought it; Kirby then said, "To tell you the truth, we picked it up in the Commercial-road to sell for some beer;" I said they might put it into the scale, and while they did that I saw the officer, and gave charge of them.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you ever bought things of this kind before? A. No.

THOMAS SHELSWELL
. I am an officer. On the 10th of September, I was near Skipp's shop; he took me in - there were these two gratings and frame - I asked the prisoners if they belonged to them; Sullivan said, No; I asked Skipp's men who brought them, and one of them said the two prisoners - I then asked Sullivan where he got the truck; he said, "From Collins, a wheel wright;" I put the prisoners into two different lock-up rooms, then went to Sullivan and said, "I suspect they belong to the Commercial-road Trust;" he said, "You have just guessed it?" I then went to Kirby and asked him where they got it - he said he knew nothing about them - that he was employed by Sullivan.
Cross-examined. Q. He said, "You have guessed it," not"You have guessed right?" A. No; and Kirby said he had helped the other - I asked them about it to get the truth.
Re-examined. Q. Did you make them any promise or threat? A. No.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GEORGE PARKER BIDDER
. I am superintendent of the new works on the Commercial-road; Christopher Richardson, the elder, and a great many others are Commissioners; I know these to be ours, by the exact similarity; they are from a pattern made specially for the use of our road; Sullivan was employed on the road, but had left about a fortnight; he had been employed several months in pitching the road; he knew the road.

Cross-examined. Q. Is there any private-mark on the property of the Commercial-road? A. Not on the grating- Messrs. Hunter and English, of Bow, are the manufacturers; it would be a breach of trust in the manufacturers to send the same sort of grating to other people; the pattern is not common.
Re-examined. Q. Do you know of any road near the Commercial-road that has such articles on it? A. No; there is no other road undergoing any improvement.
Sullivan's Defence. A man came and asked if we wanted a job - we said Yes, and we went down to where this grating laid.

THOMAS FOWLER
. I am a sailor. I was going down the Commercial-road, and about the Halfway-house I met these prisoners; I knew Sullivan, and stopped talking with him; a man came and said he would give him a job; he said he had a heavy load, and he must get a truck and another man; Kirby said, "I am here;" they went and got a truck, and he took them to where the grating was, and told them to take it to Back-church-lane.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Where do you live? A. In Essex-street; this was between three and four o'clock, on Friday, the 10th of September - I was in a public-house four days afterwards, and one of their friends came and asked the favour of me to come and say what I knew.

JAMES BOWMAN
. I am a letter-founder. I was with the last witness, and we met the prisoners; I know Sullivan was one - I am not certain of the other; a gentleman came up, dressed in black clothes - he asked if they wanted a job - Sullivan said, "Yes, if you will employ us;" he said, "If you will get a truck, I will give you a job to carry some grating down to Church-lane" - Sullivan said he could get a truck and he must pay for it; he said he should want another man, and the other said, "Here I am."

SULLIVAN -
GUILTY . Aged 28.

KIRBY -
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Confined Six Months .

1817.
JOSEPH MORRIA
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of September , 1 till, value 6d., and 5 shillings , the property of
Sophia Miller
.

SOPHIA MILLER. I keep an oil-shop in Spa-fields
. Last Friday evening, between nine and ten o'clock, I was in the back parlour, and heard a noise of money; I went into the shop, and saw the prisoner going out with the till in his hand - it had 5s. and some halfpence in it; I am quite sure he is the boy .

WILLIAM HAYNES
. I am a shoemaker. I heard the cry of Stop thief! I saw the prosecutrix picking up the till - she said the boy had run down the walk; I ran and caught the prisoner.

WILLIAM MARCH
. I took the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 15. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1818.
ELLEN EDINGTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , 2 handkerchiefs, value 2s.; 1 crown-piece, and 2 shillings, the property of
John Foster
, from his person .

ELIZABETH SALMON
. I knew
John Foster
- he is gone to sea ; I met him with the prisoner on the 10th of August, between ten and eleven o'clock; my sister was with me - he recognized me, and went to give us something to drink; he gave the prisoner a crown-piece to pay for the liquor - she put the change in her own pocket; we came out all together, and Foster said, "I have lost my money" - the prisoner then met another woman, and asked her to go into another public-house; while they were there the man said he had lost his money - I followed the prisoner, and saw her pay some money with some halfpence; I said, "You have robbed that man" - she made no reply; I went and told the prosecutor - I then went back; the prisoner was gone - I went and saw her; I said, "You have robbed that man" - she said it was of no consequence; I saw the Policeman, and gave her in charge - we went back to the prosecutor; he was gone to sleep.
Prisoner. Q. How many times have you been here? A. Never in my life.

CHARLES FIELDER
. I took up the prisoner; I found 2s. 6d. in silver on her, and in her shoe a crown-piece - I found two handkerchiefs, which the prosecutor identified; he claimed them in her presence, and she owned before the Magistrate that she was guilty - she said nothing about the money.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not own to me that you heard this woman demand the money of me? A. No, I did not; on taking her to the station I said, "What money have you got belonging to Foster?" she said she had 2s.

Prisoner's Defence. I met the prosecutor - he was very much in liquor; he desired me to go down Gravel-lane - he bought some fruit, and put it into this handkerchief; we then went to a public-house, and had five pints of gin - the witness and another woman were there; he desired me to go and get some oysters - this woman came and demanded part of the 5s. piece, and she said if I did not give it her she would say I had robbed him.

JAMES LEA
. I am an officer. Salmon has been tried here three times, and twice this year.
NOT GUILTY .

1819.
SARAH DRISCOLL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , 1 coat, value 2l., and 1 purse, value 2d. , the goods of
William Flyn
.

WILLIAM FLYN
. I am a labourer . On Tuesday, the 15th of September, I was in bed in Charlotte-court, Whitechapel
, in my own room - this coat was in my box, and there was a purse there; they were gone in the morning - the prisoner came to see a lodger of mine, and slept there on the Saturday and Sunday night.

WILLIAM CATTELL
. I am a pawnbroker. This coat was pawned with me by a woman, but I cannot swear who it was.

JAMES LEA
. I am an officer. Yesterday week the prosecutor brought the prisoner to the office - he stated he had picked up this pocket, which the prisoner dropped, in theroad to the office: I found in it the duplicate of this coat, and another duplicate in the name of Flyn - the prisoner said the pocket did not belong to her.

WILLIAM FLYN
. I took the prisoner, and as I was going along the street I saw this pocket drop, which had this purse and duplicate in it, and this other duplicate, which I had had in my box.

WILLIAM CATTELL
. I gave this duplicate for the coat.
Prisoner. There was another woman, who claimed the pocket as her own.
WILLIAM FLYN. Yes, she was with me, and said she had lost it, with 14s. 6d. in it, from under her head.

ELIZABETH ACKROY
. I saw the prisoner coming out of the house on the Tuesday evening, about nine o'clock.
Prisoner. Q. Where did you see me in the house? A. I heard some person creep up stairs, and then I saw you go out - it might be about nine o'clock.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, declaring that the pocket had not fallen from her.

GUILTY . Aged 29. -
Confined Six Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1819.
MARY DORKIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
John Palmer
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1820.
SARAH CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of August , 1 thread-case, value 3d.; 3 half-crowns, 4 sixpences, and 8d. in copper monies, the property of
George Keele
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1821.
WILLIAM CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , 1 pair of shoes, value 2s. , the goods of
Alexander Cowan
.

ALEXANDER COWAN. I am a salesman , and live in Aylesbury-street
. On the 4th of August these shoes hung against my window; I saw the prisoner come and cut them, or with a book take them off - I pursued him, and cried Stop thief! he threw them over Mr. Farmer's gate, in St. John-street; Waddington took him; as we brought him back Mr. Farmer brought out the shoes, and gave them to us.

GEORGE WADDINGTON
. I met the prisoner running, and took him - I found this piece of iron on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. It is the first time - I beg for mercy.
The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY . Aged 18. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1822.
EDWARD CORCORAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of September , 3 sovereigns, 16 shillings, and 1 sixpence , the monies of
William Lewis Thornborrow
.

WILLIAM LEWIS THORNBORROW. I have a small independence , and went to receive it on Wednesday, the 16th of September - I met the prisoner, whom I knew; I asked how he fared - he said but badly; I proposed to give him a good dinner and a shilling, which I did, and left four sovereigns in possession of the landlady; on the Thursday morning he called on me again, and asked if he could do me any little service - I said Yes, he might brush my clothes and clean my shoes; he took the papers out of my pocket, and found the note of the four sovereigns, which I had left with Mrs. Crouch - he took it, and got the balance; I had drawn 3s. 6d. the night before.

ANN CROUCH
. The last witness left me four sovereigns and a friend of mine wrote this paper; I gave it to the prosecutor - the prisoner brought it next morning, and said he came for the money, which I gave him; there were three sovereigns and 16s. 6d. - he had had 3s. 6d. of me the night before.

Prisoner. He got drunk the day before, and I took him from this lady's house - he would have a cab, and sent me back for 3s. 6d. to pay for it; he then sent me back for 1l., but I could not get that - he told me to call on him the next morning, which I did; he got out of bed, and told me to sit down - he sent for some gin, and we had four half-pints one after the other; he had promised me some time before, that when he got this money he would assist me - I asked him then to do it; he gave me this paper, and told me to go and get it, and to pay him so much a week.

W. L. THORNBORROW. There is not a word of truth in it - I had not seen him for nine months before; I wrote a petition for him to get re-established in the Police, where he had been before, but lost his situation; he showed me some names of characters - he had an unfavourable answer sent back; I was perfectly sober.

ANN CROUCH re-examined. Q. Did the prisoner come back for 3s. 6d. the same night? A. Yes; he returned in ten minutes, said the man must have a cab, and requested me to let him have 3s. 6d., which I did - he wanted a sovereign, but I would not let him have that.
NOT GUILTY .

1823.
SUSANNAH BURGETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 silver rule, value 5s., and 1 ring, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
John Woods
.

MARY WOODS
. I am the wife of John Woods, and live in Pleasant-row, Camden-town
. The prisoner lived with me for eleven months and a fortnight - she left on the 20th of July; I missed several articles, and among the rest a ring.

ELIZABETH HIDER
. The prisoner used to come to my mother's to wash - after she left the prosecutor she gave me a ring, which I think was this; I do not believe it is gold - my husband said it was not worth 1s. 6d.; I gave it to Mrs. Wood - the prisoner asked if it would fit me; I tried it on, and it did.
Prisoner. I said I found it, and it was not mine; if it was inquired for she was to give it up.

WILLIAM JAMES
. I took the prisoner - I went to her lodging, at time o'clock in the evening; she was not at home - I waited till about ten; she then came, and said,"I understand you say I have robbed you;" the prosecutrix said, "Yes, and where is the rule?" she said, "I took it out of the fire-place" - she then asked where the ring was; she said, "I saw no ring" - we went to her lodging; she made use of very bad language, and said if the apprentice had given up the silver rule he was a d-d fool; she said she had wanted to go over the water for four years, and if the prosecutor would send her there it would save her the expence.

HENRY ATHERFOLD
. I am the prosecutor's apprentice. The prisoner gave me this rule, and said she had it given to her - she gave it me for a keepsake; I lost it threemonths afterwards - I asked her for it; she said it was in the jewellery box - I said, "I will ask for it;" she said,"No, I will get it."
Prisoner's Defence. The child had it to play with, and it fell out of the box; I did not see it afterwards.
NOT GUILTY .

1824.
JOHN BARRETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , 3 sovereigns, the monies of
James Burgoyne
, from his person .

The
prosecutor did not appear NOT GUILTY .

1825.
REBECCA ALDRIDGE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 2 gowns, value 5s.; 2 aprens, value 2s.; 1 shift, value 1s.; 9 caps, value 5s.; 3 towels, value 2s.; 2 napkins, value 1s.; 3 petticoats, value 2s.; 3 night-gowns, value 2s.; 1 hair-brush, value 6d.; 4 combs, value 2s., and 2 tooth-brushes, value 6d. , the goods of
Mary Bland
.

MARY BLAND
. I left my trunk, containing the articles stated, at Mr. McGowan's, on the 27th of July, when I went to Marylebone workhouse to be confined - when I got out I went for my box, and the landlady told me the prisoner had been and taken my box and her own; I had never allowed her to take the box or the articles; she had left there- I never heard of her till within three weeks, when she was in the workhouse; I went there with an officer - I found her with my cap on her head.
Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Have you any other name but Mary? A. My name is Mary Ann, but I always went by the name of Mary; I have never been called Mary Ann since I was a child.

ISABELLA BURGOYNE
. The prosecutrix left a trunk at my house, it was locked; the prisoner came, said she came for her own box and for Mary's, and asked what there was to pay - I said nothing at all, and asked what she was going to do with Mary's; she said, to take it to the workhouse - I only knew the prosecutrix by the name of Mary.

ANN FOY
. The prisoner became a lodger where I was- I pawned two or three articles by her orders.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you receive the articles from her? A. At a house where I worked; I did not assist in opening the box - I was on the opposite side of the kitchen when it was opened; the prisoner said Mary had got the key in a mistake, and she must have it opened, as she wanted something.
COURT. Q. Did Mary Bland authorize you to take any of the things? A. No.

HENRY HAYES
. I am a shopman to Mr. Baylis, a pawnbroker.
Ann Foy
pawned a petticoat for 1s., a gown for 2s., and some other things with me.

JOHN ANDREWS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and produce these articles, which the prosecutrix identified- I took this cap off the prisoner's head.
MARY BLAND. These are all mine.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not break the box.

GUILTY . Aged 22. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1826.
WILLIAM ALLSOP
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of July , one 10l. Bank note , the property of
Henry Pickford
.

ELIZABETH PICKFORD. I am the wife of
Henry Pickford
; he is in the 3rd regiment of Foot Guards. On the 12th of July, the prisoner was pot-boy at the Canteen, in Portman-street - my husband is pay-serjeant of his company; the prisoner came that evening to know if I wanted any beer - I told him what beer to bring, and told him to ask his master to give me change for a 10l. note; he returned with the beer, and said I could not have the change that evening, but as early as six o'clock in the morning I might; I said I did not want it so soon, when my husband came off duty would be time enough - he came the next morning, and asked if I had the paper; I then gave him the note to get the change, and never saw him afterwards till he was apprehended on the 17th of August - I never got the note or the money.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. Did not you say you gave him the note that evening? A. No, in the morning; I asked if I could have the change - I never saw him after I gave it into his hand - I positively swear that; I will swear he did not come back, say his master could not give me change, and I tell him to get change elsewhere - I saw him go towards his master's with the note; I believe my husband had leave from Mr. Conant to compromise the matter.

HENRY PEARSON
. I am the publican. The prisoner came to me with the note, and asked if I could give change - I said I could not; he went away, and came back in ten minutes and asked again - I said I could not; he said he must go and get change; he went out, and did not return.
Cross-examined. Q. Had he the note with him? A. Yes, the second time, but not the first - he asked for change for Mrs. Pickford.

DANIEL CHAPMAN
. I was sent for to apprehend the prisoner on the 17th of August - I asked if he had had the note; he said Yes, and he had spent it - that as soon as he found his master could not give him change, he saw some soldiers, and said to them, "Come along with me, and have a spree, I have plenty of money now."

JOB JEFFRIES
. I am a corporal in the 3rd regiment of Guards. The prisoner came to me on the morning of the 13th of July, a little before ten o'clock; he had some money in his hand, and asked me to give him some more to get a pot of beer - I said I would not; in about ten minutes he came again, and said he had a 10l. note.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you attend the first examination? A. No, but the serjeant asked me about it one morning - I attended on the last examination; this was on Tuesday morning, the 13th of July - I remember it very well; I will swear it was Tuesday, the 13th of July.
GUILTY. Aged 25.

Recommended to Mercy -
Confined Six Months .

1827.
MARY JOLLY
was indicted for that
she, on the 17th of July , being servant to
John Penny
, did embezzle 10 shillings, his monies .
The prisoner not being servant to the prosecutor, was ACQUITTED .

1828.
ANN WOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , 3 sheets, value 15s.; 5 table-cloths, value 20s.; 2 shirts, value 10s.; 4 spoons, value 7s., and 1 bed-gown, value 2s. , the goods of
John Smith
.

ELEANOR SMITH
. I am the wife of John Smith; we live in Marchmont-place
: the prisoner lodged in our house - I missed this property last Sunday week from my apartment - she had access to the house - I never permitted her to pawn any thing.

JOHN JONES
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Theobald's-road. I have three sheets and two table-cloths, pawned by the prisoner.

BENJAMIN SMITH
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a shirt, a table-cloth, three tea-spoons, and a bed-gown, pawned by the prisoner.
ELEANOR SMITH. This is all my property - she lived with her son, who has the front room; I think it is through her husband's leaving her that she did this.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, pleading distress.

GUILTY . Aged 45. -
Confined Twelve Months .

1829.
MARY VENEAL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 1 sheet, value 1s., and 1 apron, value 6d. , the goods of
Sarah Rayment
.

SARAH RAYMENT. I am a widow , and live in Wellington-street, Bethnal-green-road
; the prisoner lodged and slept with me - she was a weaveress - I knew her about four months; she went away one Saturday evening, and on the Sunday I missed this property - I inquired after her, but did not find her, till she was brought to the Police-station.

MARY REYNOLDS
. I bought this duplicate of the sheet of the prisoner, it cost me 2s. 1d.; she owned she took it - I took it out and pawned it again.

GEORGE MILLINGTON
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Bethnal-green-road - I took in this sheet of the prisoner on the 27th of July.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I worked there five months, and on finishing my work I asked her to lend me 1s.; she refused, but said I might take these things to pawn.
SARAH RAYMENT. She did not ask me to lend her 1s.; I knew nothing of her till she came there to lodge.
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

1830.
HANNAH SPURRIER
, and
PHOEBE WALTERS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of September , 1 watch, value 4l.; 1 seal, value, 10s.; 1 key, value 1s., and 1 purse, value 1s. , the goods of
Joseph Shaw
.

JOSEPH SHAW. I am servant to a gentleman in Whitehall-place. On the 19th of September, between twelve and one o'clock at night - I had been out spending the evening, but I knew what I was about - I passed the prisoners in Peter-street
; they turned round and followed me - they asked me to go to a house, which I did, and they wished to have something to drink - I gave Walters some silver to go and get something - she went out, and I remained with Spurrier - I pulled out my watch, and said I should not stop above twenty minutes - when Walters came back with the liquor - one of them (I believe Walters) put out the candle, and made some excuse to go out - I had put my watch on the table, but I believe one of them had pulled out the table-drawer, and put the watch into it - Walters did not return - the candle being out, I felt uncomfortable, and desired to have a light; at that moment I heard something dangling, as Spurrier went across the room; I did not hear any thing tick, but only rattle - I followed her, and she passed very quick into a room opposite; I said, "Where is my watch?" she said she had not got it, and she knew nothing about it - I insisted upon a light, but no light was produced; I then threw up the window, called the Police, and gave charge of Spurrier - he found nothing on her; the other had absconded altogether - there was a third person in the house, whom I had not seen; I gave information, and the Policeman took Walters with the watch in the morning.

GEORGE BOWEN
. I am a Police-constable; my attention was called by the prosecutor - I went, took Spurrier, I searched the room, and the next room - I found nothing, but 4s. 6d.; I took Spurrier that night, and went in search of Walters, at No. 7, in the Almonry - I questioned her whether she would open the door, or I would break it open - I found her in bed, and this watch under her head.

JOSEPH SHAW
. This is my watch.
COURT. Q. Did you make them any present? A. Yes, I did to Spurrier - I certainly did not see or know that my watch was in the room.

Spurrier's Defence. I met him in York-street about ten o'clock; he went with us, and sent Walters for 1s. worth of gin and cloves, then for another, and for four or five - he made me quite tipsy, and I went to bed; he undressed, and went to bed too.

Walters' Defence. When I went in with the last gin and cloves, he said he was sorry he had not money to pay for more, and he gave me his watch; I then went to bed, and he grumbled at three of us being in bed - I got up and went to another bed.

JOSEPH SHAW
. I never thought of stopping all night; I did not give the watch to either of them; I gave Spurrier 3s. 6d. or 4s., and it might be 2s. or 3s. I gave Walters for liquor.
JURY. Q. Were you so intoxicated you did not know what you gave? A. Certainly not.

SPURRIER -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

WALTERS -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1831.
THOMAS LEWIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of September , 1 hogshead, value 6s. , the goods of
John Wright
.

JOHN WRIGHT
. I am a wine and spirit-merchant , and live in Ratcliff-highway
- the prisoner was not in my service. On the 18th of September, about seven o'clock in the evening, a person rang at my door, and asked if I had authorised a man to take a cask away from the gateway; I said No; and asked him to go after him - he did, and brought back the prisoner, who had got three or four houses off.

GEORGE OSBORN
. I saw the prisoner bring out the hogshead; when I stopped him, he said a man had promised to pay him for it, but I saw no man.
Prisoner's Defence. I was standing; a person asked if I wanted a job - I said Yes; and he told me to roll the cask to Tower-hill.

GUILTY . Aged 24. -
Confined Six Weeks .

1832.
WILLIAM HERRING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of September , 1 snuff-box, value 3s., the goods of
John Anderson
, from his person .

JOHN ANDERSON. I was in Crown-street
on Saturday last between twelve and one o'clock - I was going home and saw a disturbance; I went with a friend to see what it was - I felt a tug at my pocket, turned, and missed my box; I saw the prisoner working his way through thecrowd, and calling to another person; I seized him, called the Policeman, and gave him in charge; the moment I did that I saw him throw something down an area - we took him to a public-house, and found my snuff-box in his left-hand coat pocket, and the next morning the private watchman found my friend's snuff-box down the area - there had been no snuff in mine; this is my box - it appeared to me the prisoner had some one with him; he called to some one.

PETER JACKSON
. I am a Policeman. I took the prisoner, and found this box in his left-hand coat pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 14. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
OLD COURT. FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 24.
First Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1833.
WILLIAM SULLIVAN
and
JEREMIAH CORCORAN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , 1 coat, value 10s. , the goods of
John Nichols
.

JOHN NICHOLS
. I am a labourer . On the 18th of July I was at the Rose and Crown, St. Giles'
- it was a very wet afternoon; I went to have a pint of beer - my coat was wet; I pulled it off, and while I was unbuttoning it Sullivan said, "What do you want for that old coat, old chap?" I said I would not take less than 10s. for it; he came and laid hold of it, and said, "Let me fit it on;" he took it, and put it on - Corcoran was sitting by his side, drinking with him; he was going out with the coat on - I pushed him back, and said, "Don't go away with my coat;" Corcoran instantly pulled me back, and held me back while Sullivan ran out with the coat, and then he followed him - I went into the passage, but did not know which door they ran out at; I described them to two Policeman.

EDWARD DAVIS
. I am a Policeman. Nichols described the prisoners to me: I knew them from his description, and found them both in bed together, at one o'clock in the morning - I took Sullivan, but did not then know Corcoran was concerned - he was afterwards taken; I found the prosecutor's coat on the bed.
Sullivan. The man himself put the coat on my back, and offered to sell it.

JOHN NICHOLS
. It is not true.

THOMAS KENNEDY
. I keep the public-house. I remember seeing Sullivan in the tap-room; I remember seeing Nichols there - I do not know Corcoran: he might be there - I saw no part of the transaction inside the house: I was in the yard - Sullivan passed me, and went out at a very quick pace, with a great coat like this on; another man followed him out quickly, but I did not see his face.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Sullivan's Defence. His coat was not wet at all - he took it off, and offered it for sale to another man, and then to me; I had not enough to purchase it, and he said if I would sell it he would stand something to drink.
Corcoran's Defence. He put the coat on Sullivan's back, and he went out with it - I went in about ten minutes, and met Sullivan very much intoxicated.

SULLIVAN -
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .

CORCORAN -
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Three Months .

1834.
WILLIAM SPRY
and
THOMAS BROWN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 6d.; 1 cap, value 2s.; 1 knife, value 6d.; 1 key, value 4d.; 1 sovereign, and 1 sixpence, the property of
John Jones
, from his person .

JOHN JONES
. I am a dealer in provisions , and live in Great Eastcheap. I got rather the worse for liquor, and was robbed of this property, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, as I was going home - I recollect very little of the circumstance.

WILLIAM CLEMENTS
. I am a Police-officer. I was on duty in St. John-street, St. Sepulchre's
- I had information that something was going on wrong, and went to the spot: I found the prosecutor standing with his back against the wall, very drunk - the two prisoners were surrounding him up a court, which is not a thoroughfare; they had got their hands about his person - I asked what they were doing with the man; they said they had merely brought him there to ease himself - I asked what business they had to bring him up there; they said they did not like to see him do it in the street - I asked what they had got about them - they said they had nothing; I searched them, and found in Spry's hat a handkerchief, and another handkerchief inside - I asked if both belonged to him; he said they did- I turned round to Jones; he said the red handkerchief was his - I took both the prisoners into custody; they wanted to rush past me - I said if they did I would cut them down with my truncheon, and if I had not been resolute they would have got away; I found a black cloth cap in Spry's hat, which Jones did not claim at the time, but next morning he inquired for it - when I got Jones to the watch-house, I asked if he had lost any money; he said he did not know, for he was very drunk.

Cross-examined by MR. HEATON. Q. The prosecutor was drunk? A. Yes, and did not know what he was doing - some of his buttons were undone, and somebody had certainly been there for the purpose they stated; I will not swear their hands were in his pockets, but they were about them - they were not assisting to button up his braces; I do not consider that it was their duty to assist him, there were plenty of Police about; I found nothing on Brown - I found a towel and handkerchief in Spry's hat: Jones did not claim them - there is a gas lamp in the court.

JAMES LEE
. I am a private watchman. I found a knife and key on the window-cill, near the spot, directly after the prisoners were brought to the station.
Cross-examined. Q. Many other persons might have been in the court? A. There is a wicket-gate at the end of it; it was about twenty minutes past eleven o'clock.

THOMAS ENGLAND
. I am a carpenter. I was the first who went up the court after the prisoners were taken - I found a sovereign and a sixpence lying there on the ground.
Cross-examined. Q. Was it an hour after the prisoners had been there? A. I think it was a little after eleven o'clock.

JOHN JONES
. I had borrowed this red handkerchief that evening - I lost a black cloth cap from my pocket that night; I believe the knife to be mine - I am certain the key is mine; I had a sovereign and some silver inmy breeches pocket, and 10s. or 12s. were left; I might have had 1s. in the same pocket as the gold.

Cross-examined. Q. Do not you know that you had a shilling and sixpence in the same pocket? A. I am not positive; I believe I had eased myself in the court - the money might have come from the pocket while doing so; I had been to the Crown-tavern, Clerkenwell.

Spry's Defence. As we were in St. John-street, the prosecutor came up, put his arms round our necks, and asked where we were going; we asked if we should see him home - he said Yes; he said he wanted to ease himself - we took him up a turning; he fell down - England came up the court, and brought the Police; the prosecutor said he believed the handkerchief was his - the Magistrate asked for the cap, and they said it was at the station, but it could not be found.

WILLIAM CLEMENTS
. I am certain the cap was in his hat; I emptied the contents of the hat on the ground.
NOT GUILTY .

1835.
JOHN ROBERTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , 1 hat, value 7s. , the goods of
Samuel Herapath
and
Elias Sylvester
.

WILLIAM DAY
. I am apprentice to Samuel Herapath and
Elias Sylvester
, hatter
s, Tothill-street, Westminster
. On the 24th of September, about twenty-five minutes past ten o'clock, I had four hats hanging at the door - I left a boy in the shop, who went to sleep; a witness gave an alarm, I ran out, and pursued the prisoner, who was secured by a Policeman.

WILLIAM SCARDFIELD
. I saw the prisoner take a hat from the door, put it on his head, and run off; he had no hat of his own - I gave an alarm, and am sure he is the man.

DANIEL RIERDON
. I am an officer. I stopped the prisoner in Broadway soon after this happened, and took the hat off his head.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was standing at the corner of Broadway - a young man, whom I frequently drank with, came up intoxicated; I was looking at a quarrel in the street - he pulled this hat off his head, took a cap out of it, and began swearing; I said, "What is the matter?" he said, "I have bought a hat, and wish I had not bought it, for I want the money more;" I bought it of him for 5s. 6d., and had not had it on five minutes before I was taken.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .
NEW COURT. FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 24.
Fourth Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Serjeant.

1836.
HENRY TOOZE NORTHAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , 1 coat, value 15s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 13s., and 1 waistcoat, value 5s ., the goods of
Thomas Jones
.

THOMAS JONES
. I am a coach-smith . On the 10th of August I lost a coat, waistcoat, and trousers from my box- I had seen them safe on the 9th; the prisoner lodged and slept with me for three or four years - my box was broken open.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe you have been on the most intimate terms? A. No - we had not occasionally lent each other money and clothes to pawn; he never pawned my clothes with my consent.

Q. Did you not swear before the Magistrate that you lived like brothers - that he had often pawned your clothes, but brought them back very honestly, and you had no doubt he would this time? A. I do not recollect it - I will not swear I did not; I was so agitated, I hardly know what I said - if I said so, very likely it was so.

GEORGE KING
. I am a pawnbroker. I received these clothes from the prisoner on the 10th of August - I knew him before; he has regularly pawned in his own name - he had pawned wearing-apparel and redeemed it, for years.
NOT GUILTY .

1837.
WILLIAM JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , 1 looking-glass, value 8s. , the goods of
William Henry Colton
.

WILLIAM HENRY COLTON
. I am a carver and gilder , and live at Islington
. On the 6th of August I was returning to my shop, about twelve o'clock - I saw a man standing one door from my shop, and as I got to my door I met the prisoner coming out with this glass; I went and asked my wife if she had sold it - she said No; I followed the prisoner and the other man - he threw the glass against a fence; I pursued, and took him.
Prisoner. The looking-glass was standing at the door. Witness. No, it was inside, on a wash-hand stand.

CHARLES WRIGHT
. I am a Police-constable. I received charge of the prisoner - he told me a man had employed him to carry it, and he was to receive 1s.; the prosecutor desired me to keep him while he pursued the other, but he got away.

THOMAS MOULTON
. I saw the prisoner throw away the glass - I took it up.
Prisoner. I did it through distress.

GUILTY . Aged 20 -
Transported for Seven Years .

1838.
JOHN HARDY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2nd of September , 1 sovereign, and 3 1/2d. in copper , the monies of
John Pipe
.

JOHN PIPE. I lost this money on the 2nd of September, from my shop, in King-street, St. Giles'
. I saw the prisoner take it from the till about nine o'clock at night; I went into the shop before he put the money into his pocket - I went in; he took out 3 1/2d., and said that was all he had taken - I kept him, I dare say, an hour, when the officer came and took him; I had searched him before the officer came, and found 1s. 1d. on him - he had taken the sovereign before from a parcel which I sent him out with; he was in my employ.

HENRY CURTIS
. The prisoner was brought in custody - I found nothing on him; I said, "What did you do with the sovereign?" he said he had been to Chelsea, and spent it - he had bought a piece of music and a knife.
NOT GUILTY .

1839.
JOHN McDONALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23rd of August, 1 shirt, value 2s. 3d. , the goods of
John Boards
; to which he
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 49. -
Confined One Month .

1840.
GEORGE VILLIERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Thomas Perronet Thompson
, from his person ; to which he
pleaded GUILTY . Aged 38. -
Transported for Fourteen Years .
